description:
This place was so tasty and my then-fiance and I loved the vibe! There was plenty to choose from on the menu, so we both got something we enjoyed. The area in which Chubby Noodle is located is a good area too, which was nice because we encountered a few weird things on the streets of San Fran! 

I'd definitely go back here.
author: Sherie K.

description:
If you want good vibes, check this place out. If you want good Asian food, skip this place. 
-Server wasn't friendly, but the hip ambience compensated well-enough for me to not think much about it
-The fried chicken was bomb, loved the dipping sauce that came with it. Enjoyed the portion-size
-Would not get the ramen again
author: Holly P.

description:
I LOVE cubby noodle - but that love was cultivated at the marina location. Where the rap playlist was amazing, waiters were hilarious and rubber duckies  were a plenty. Fast forward to moving to north beach, 2 blocks from their NB location. What a horribly different experience. Namely bc of a waiter named Evan along with another gal there who kept citing that she was tired to excuse for the mean service. To start with Evan - he hilariously told us which dishes were shit and that he'd just not bring them out, and when we asked for what we wanted, he let us know that they don't do boxes and all wasted food gets thrown away... like oh really bro? Food gets thrown away in this city and it's OUR fault?! Then when we asked to buy a bottle of sake, he let us know he needs to get the table ready for their 12 reso... it was ELEVEN and the place was EMPTY. Alright Evan, got you loud and clear. Word to the wise homie, find a job where it's normal to be an absolute effing prick. Don't ruin such an awesome place and brand with your bullshit attitude. 

Btw stars are for delicious food and drink....nothing else.
author: Sheena S.

description:
When I first heard this place was all you can eat AND bottomless drinks AND a Chinese restaurant I honestly didn't believe it. But surprisingly enough, Chubby Noodle does exist and they offer a the brunch deal for $45.

The only down side is that for people who aren't capable of drinking as much (myself) then it's hard to get the full bang for your buck. But regardless, the food was great and they let you try every dish (upon request). My favorite dish was probably the pepper shrimp. It was so flavorful and crunchy and also came with this dipping sauce that made it so much better. I was surprised I liked the shrimp so much since normally I think shrimp are weird, but yeah, it's that good. 

The drinks are good too, the day I went they had sangria and a watermelon mimosa. The sangria was definitely better, though, and they even add a cute tiny rubber duck inside the drinks, haha. I may have walked out of the restaurant with one or two rubber ducks. Overall, this place is so much fun to enjoy with friends and the 2 hour time limit was just enough to eat, drink, and get a lil tipsy ;)
author: Hailey M.

description:
Well I'm just OBSESSED with this spot. 
I literally feel obligated to take anyone here who hasn't been yet. I've made 4 trips recently to bring my visiting friends, and everyone seems to LOVE it just as much as I do. 

I can't leave without the pork tacos and pork buns - they are just so melt-in-your-mouth amazing I feel like I dream about them at this point. The garlic noodles with fried chicken and the beef chow mein are also delicious so I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu really.
author: Hanna S.

description: Great food. Their chubby noodles are very delicious and so is the crispy cauliflower. They have a good collection of sparkling wines as well
author: Lovereen K.

description: Super small space but we were able to grab some seats at the bar. I usually don't like Chinese fusion food but this place was great! We did the chubby noodles, Asian tacos, fried rice, fried chicken and green beans. It was a lot of food for three people but we managed to finish everything. The tacos were definitely the best - the meat was so juicy and flavorful and the perfect way to start the meal. The chubby noodles had a very interesting taste to it that was good but I don't think I would order it again.
author: Jen L.

description:
Came here for the all you can eat brunch on Sundays. The service was phenomenal! Even though they had so many people to serve, the servers were super attentive and got whatever we needed. The music and ambiance are great.

Now on to the food, my favorites are the chicken wings, the tacos, shrimp and the watermelon memosa. I could honestly eat and drink these all day. The chicken wings are perfectly baked and the tacos are just amazing (think peking duck but with chicken). The other stuff on the menu is decent but not knock your pants off (I would avoid the korean vermicelli, its a bit bland).

Its definitely a great place to grab a ton of food with some friends (make sure you make a reservation). A bit pricey but I think well worth it in quantity.
author: Taylor Z.

description:
We had a yummy dinner at Chubby Noodle in North Beach. This is actually Chubby Noodle's second location. It opened in June 2015. The original, located in the Marina District, opened in May 2014. This is a popular Asian restaurant and bar serving modern, fusion-type fare along with sake, cocktails, beer, and wine.

We walked in around 6pm on a Thursday and there wasn't a wait. However, when we left around 7pm, there was a wait. This place isn't terribly big, but it's not tiny either. I'd guesstimate they have seating for roughly 40-50 customers, bar and dining room combined. They're able to accommodate larger groups (5+), but only 1 or 2 at a time. The space consists of a combination of 4-person booths and tables with both bench and stool (no backs) seating. Booths are definitely the way to go here. You can call the restaurant to book reservations.

The restaurant has a simple, clean, and contemporary design. The build-out and furniture still look and feel relatively new. The interior has an Asian flair with lots of light woods (some of which resemble bamboo), suspended paper lanterns, and bar decor such as a Laughing Buddha statue and an assortment of Japanese teapots. The storefront has two windows which were open during our visit. These gave the inside a bit of an open-air feel. The atmosphere was casual and relaxed and the music that played was early 2000s hip hop and R&B.

The menu has more adult beverage options than it does food options. There are a little over 20 dishes to choose from, from cucumber salad and kimchi ($4 each) to tuna poke ($16) and pork ribs ($17). As for the "noodle" aspect of Chubby Noodles, they offer 5 different kinds of noodles: spicy garlic egg noodles, ramen, chow mein, curry lemongrass vermicelli, and pad Thai ($13-16 each, toppings extra).

Here's what we tried:

* Steamed pork buns - shredded pork, shiitake mushrooms, napa cabbage, Thai chili, hoisin (3 for $13)
* Spicy garlic noodles - egg noodles, charred garlic, jalapeno, cilantro, and fried chicken ($13 for the noodles and $5 for the fried chicken)
* Pork ribs - Coleman Ranch pork, jalapeno, vinegar soy glaze ($17)

We enjoyed everything. The food was delicious. The ingredients were good quality and each dish looked great and was presented beautifully.

The steamed pork buns were served in a dim-sum-style bamboo basket complete with lid. Each steamed pork bun came with a generous amount of shredded pork *and* chunks of rich and fatty pork belly (the latter wasn't mentioned on the menu, so it was a pleasant surprise). The pork was soft, tender, and well-seasoned with excellent flavor. The steamed buns were chewy and pillowy.

The spicy garlic noodles were fantastic. The egg noodles were thick and delectable. They were coated in a savory, addictive sauce. The fried chicken that we added on was worth it. It was lightly breaded and boneless. It came with a creamy sambal sauce on the side which looked similar to and sort of tasted like Sriracha mayo or a spicy chili aioli. Yum.

The pork ribs were terrific. There were 4-5 pieces on a plate stacked one on top of the other. The bones were big with each piece having a decent amount of meat. The meat wasn't exactly fall-off-the-bone, but it didn't have to be. It was still tender and succulent. The vinegar soy glaze was sticky and sweet. Good stuff. I recommend all of the items we had.

My buddy got a 24-ounce can of Asahi Super Dry beer for $12. I took a sip. The drink was crisp, ice cold, tasty, and refreshing.

Our server was Estefania. She was cool and friendly and did a wonderful job.

A single unisex restroom is located in the back. You have to walk through/past the kitchen to get there.
author: Daniel B.

description:
After hearing my friends rave about this place for months, I simultaneously couldn't wait to go and also didn't expect it to live up to the hype, but wow I was completely blown away! A couple things to make your experience more palatable--walk or grab a Lyft, you're not going to have a fun time parking, and try to go for a little off dinner; either 6 or a little before 9, but not regular dinner hours cause you'll be waiting a while. 

The food was spectacular. We ordered garlic noodles, pork buns, tacos, and salmon sashimi. Sashimi was fresh and citrusy, which I normally don't like but it worked well with the sauce they sat it in. Tacos were definitely interesting, and I loved the sauce the pork was tossed in. 

The garlic noodles with fried chicken are a must try. They're perfectly spicy and chewy, and the texture goes so well with the crispy chicken. One bowl is enough for a good serving size between three. The bao dough was super fluffy and the pork was tender and had just the right amount of sauce. Service was quick and efficient, and the sake flights are great if you like to try a little of everything!
author: Leah V.

description:
Great dinner here recently with friends on a Friday night.
Totally lived up to high expectations based on a recommendation. 
We had:

Crispy cauliflower - absolutely delicious with little slices of fried jalapeño and a nice tangy dipping sauce
Green beans - served "stir fried" in a dark sauce that was salty & sweet
Korean pork tacos - super yummy and generous portion of pork 
Pork ribs - very good; enjoy the sauce with some fried rice
Spicy garlic noodles - very good; not too spicy
Steamed pork buns - beautifully prepared pork in excellent buns
Fried rice - very tasty with little chunks of pork throughout

Cannot WAIT until I can eat here again.
author: Lewis C.

description: This place lives up to the hype.  Came here for dinner and sampled the pork buns, which are flavorful, tender and delicious.  I tried the house kimchi.  I wasn't as impressed, but it was ok.  I also tried the garlic noodles.  They are the right texture and firm, not mushy.  They were flavorful but I should have added meat to them.
author: Yellowbag T.

description:
So far, this is the best meal we've had in SF. The roll of the day was a Spicy Salmon hand roll. I could've eaten 5 of them. The fish was so fresh, and the spicy sauce was great. It was definitely spicy, but not overpowering. 

We split the pork tacos and the steamed pork buns. Both were good, but the tacos were better. The soft tortillas had been toasted and has some crunch to them. We had to eat extra pork before we could fold and eat the taco. The steamed pork buns were amazing too. The buns were so soft. The pork was overflowing and was tender. 

I definitely suggest this place if you're in San Francisco.
author: Cody E.

description:
My favorite brunch spot in SF with the bottomless dim sum and drinks! We had a 10am red and honestly 90 minutes goes by fast! They're really good at bringing out everything too and the portions are great because you can try a lot of things and not get full. The staff was also super fun and engaging and gave us such good recs. The lemongrass tacos are the best here because their tortilla is thicker and more chewy than normal!'n so good. 

Highlights include:
Lemongrass chicken tacos
Fried shrimp 
Green beans
Chicken wings
Chow mein isn't bad

The drinks are great though they're really watered down.
author: Casie N.

description:
I'd give them 1 stars, but they were really patient with our table while we waited about 15-20 minutes for our last member of our party to come. 

For the food, everything was honestly so underwhelming or terribly spiced. I'm so confused how this place could have 4 stars when it's not better than classic American food or traditional Chinese food. This place shouldn't be called Asian Fusion - it should be called Elevated Panda Express. Even then, Panda Express might taste better than this place. 

I ordered the Spicy Garlic Noodles since I saw an overwhelming number of photos for that dish on here. It's something that I could have easily made myself and it would have tasted a lot better. I also shared the Kung Pao Wings with a friend, and they were incredibly spicy with no other flavor but spice. 

No pictures of the food since it was so underwhelming. Go elsewhere in Chinatown for a better and cheaper meal.
author: Bradford L.

description:
Love this little spot. I have pretty high standard for asian fusion food but this place is pretty awesome, void of mayonnaise (which seems to creep into quite a bit of asian fusion food) and fantastic value for what you pay. 

I really like ambience. The music had a lot of energy but not aggressive - Great for hanging out. 

The tuna poke was excellent - fresh fish, up there in quality with some of best places in Hawaii. 

The green beans were solid but not exceptional. 

I also saw the hamachi that they brought out which looked quite yummy. 

Will be back!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Finally got to try Chubby Noodle! 

Every time I try to make a reservation the day of for weekend brunch, they always tell me no more reservations available. Make sure you call in at least a day before! Only caveat to that is you have to make sure you know how many people is in your party, and no flakes cause there's a $25 charge per person who doesn't show. They make you put down your card info.

We sat down and then got helped by the waitress asking us what drink we wanted to try, and she recommends the pineapple mimosa. We decided to give it a try, but my drink had too much champagne and barely any pineapple juice- now I'm not complaining... but then when my friend ordered it, they got a lot of pineapple juice in contrast. Also, we didn't get the duckies when we ordered it, but later ordered drinks included the duckies. The waiters keep trying to refill your drink, but I wanted to try the sangria next. When I asked for the sangria instead, they had to take away your cup and give you a new one for your different drink because of the "no double fisting rule." However, the Sangria was really good! (The cold tea was a weird ginger not so tasty drink.)

There's supposed to be 16 dim sum items and 4 drink options. However, it was only 2 "dim sum" items or 15 food entree items, depends on how you look at it. Where's the last option though??? 

I have mixed feelings about the food honestly. Now, it wasn't bad, but it was way too salty, and not authentic dim sum, nor even Chinese food. Many of the dishes had ginger flavor where it doesn't usually, ie. pork wonton, dan dan mein, etc. but in a weird way, I also enjoyed it too. Strange thing too, the waitress more so decided for us what and how much we were going to get next. She put in an order with 3 dishes of xo rice noodles when we just wanted 1 (btw no xo sauce in it,) and we didn't like it so we didn't finish it. Granted, all dishes here were pretty small portions, great for trying, but she came by and said she was hesitant on letting us order more food cause we still have a lot of food, which btw, we didn't actually order. On the brighter note, with her pushing orders on us, we did end up getting to try everything on the menu.

Things I did like though, was the cucumber salad, the chicken wings, salt and pepper shrimp, and the eggplants. The flavoring of the food was way too overwhelming, and salty. Tbh I feel like I lost some taste buds even now!

Anyways, it was a fun experience, definitely not what I expected, but what happens when you're with a mob of Asians, eating at a non-Asian-"Asian" restaurant is that you get them to all critique food, and say "that's not really dim sum."
author: Melody W.

description:
Food is great,  service is friendly,  ambience hipster

Spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken
-noodles with good texture and lots of garlic flavor with mild spice, the sauce could stand to be a little less sweet though,  definitely doesn't need to appeal like panda express to the American public but it does
-fried chicken crispy,  juicy,  on point!  Love it

Kale salad
-YES perfect appetizer,  dressing was a good tart sweet savory light experience,  definitely would get this again

Korean pork tacos
-Kimchi slaw. .. meh
-pork overly sweet 
- skins for the taco were like the Chinese pancake style,  nice! 

Every server was friendly and had honest suggestions

The vibe was dark,  loud,  small,  with lots of hipsters/transplants dining in

Overall a good culinary experience!
author: Tina A.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night for a team event and it certainly lived up to the hype! We arrived a little early for dinner at ~5:30pm and were seated right away. 

I was stoked to see that it was "Fat Noodle Tuesday" which meant all items under the noodle category were $6 (for 1/2 portions) and sake shots were $3. 

We ordered the following items:
Two spicy garlic noodles - delicious and spicy just as advertised. 
Chow Mein - pretty solid but wish they had a non meat option.
Pork Tacos - loved these! 
Wings - solid, would eat again. 
Steamed Pork Buns - my favorite thing we ordered (I made an exception of not eating meat just for this).

Sake shots were surprising good for $3 but the team was disappointed that they didn't come with their infamous "duckies".

Great spot and I can't wait to check out their brunch next time!
author: Capers B.

description:
With its bustling and lively atmosphere with its constant stream of diners, Chubby Noodle is a great spot for a Friday night dinner. 

The service is prompt and amiable, and if you sit at the bar, you can also see the kitchen preparing the food!

Spicy Garlic Noodles (5/5) -- This is a must try. It's full of creamy, garlic flavor, and the noodles are thick and chewy. The added cilantro is a perfect addition that cuts through some of the oiliness.

Szechuan Green Beans (4.5/5) -- This is a good choice if you're looking for a vegetable dish. The added oyster sauce makes it taste a bit different from other Chinese Green Bean dishes, but no surprises here.

Chubby Fried Chicken (4/5) -- This was good and seems like a popular dish, but I probably would not order again. The quality of the chicken varied, with some being perfectly juicy while many others were dry and stringy. Wish there was more consistency here. The creamy hot sauce that comes with has is a good amount of spiciness, however.

Would love to come back for its bottomless dim sum!
author: Robert H.

description:
Simply had the spicy garlic noodle and while it was a bit spicy for my taste buds I can't deny that it was good. I'm curious if they can do it without the " heat" so to speak ?

Noodles were nice and chubby like the namesake and just flavorful. I'm confident that anyone who likes spicy food would enjoy this dish .

Gentlemen working was also super cool and friendly . Look forward to trying other dishes.
author: Rod M.

description:
Food: Shrimp Pad Thai and Chubby Fried Chicken were delicious; the spicy garlic noodles were good too although a little too spicy for me. Papaya salad was good. 
The Kobe Beef Chow Mein had lots of "stuff" in it but was my least liked...the beef doesn't match the flavor of the noodles, and the sauce was a bit salty.

Price: OK for SF and worth it for some dishes

Ambiance: nice "romantic" lighting, and the cubbies, although wooden, are pretty comfy. The music is loud though and sometime not kid friendly. Don't expect to have long sustained conversations while eating.

Service: it can be kind of awkward that they serve the food as the food is made, if you wanted to eat all ordered dishes at the same time.
author: Angela I.

description:
Like a misguided tourist I came here for brunch on a Saturday morning with my parents.  I thought this would've been a great spot where my asian parents can get a taste of the familiar with something new.   Unfortunately for me, it was the equivalent to taking my parents to a college frat party.  The restaurant was filled with laughter from sloppy guys & gals.  Although I have to say, if I was with a group of friends - it would've been a much more positive experience.  

We sat down and tried our best to keep in good spirits and ignore everything around us.  It was an uncomfortable brunch with a long wait time.  I had a pork dish which I attest to me feeling somewhat unspectacular later in the evening.  I was spewing my guts from my backend relentlessly.
author: Justin L.

description: Their most popular noodle item took over twenty minutes on a non-busy day, received two pieces of chicken ($5!!), then when I politely asked the worker to review my order, the chef proceeded to argue about the chicken pieces. As he was arguing, he put his fingers repeatedly in my food. GROSS. They finally remade the dish after another long wait and when I got home to eat it, it was the same noodle dish that was touched by his hands! Would not recommend due to sanitary reasons and lack of professionalism shown tonight.
author: Glenn L.

description:
Showed up on a Sunday with no reservation and was able to get two spots at the bar. The servers seemed a bit "uppity" but overall the guy we had was really nice and helpful. He kept the mimosas coming and informed us that the food would come out as it's made, which we were fine with.

Everything was AMAZING. The green beans, fried rice, wontons, cucumber salad, etc. I could not get enough of it and we even ordered extra. For ~$50 I'd say it's totally worth it for all you can eat/drink.
author: Rosie L.

description:
LOVE this place! fun atmosphere & music - great for brunch & group meals. the brunch menu isn't very different from the lunch/dinner menus but that's okay - next birthday for your friends i highly recommend brunch here, yes they do bottomless. I like almost everything on the menu, but my favorites are def : 

- tuna poke - they have super fresh fish & love the garlic chips to scoop it with
- spicy garlic noodles w/ chubby fried chicken - i think this might be the best thing on the menu. the noodles are killer, with a little spice and then that chickennn. man, i wish i had some right now 
- salt & pepper shrimp - lightly breaded w/ the same sauce as the chubby fried chicken & its pertfect w/ the thai basil, scallions and cilantro on top
- Szechuan green beans - that sauce thoughhhh & bring on the garlic 
- papaya salad - it's so fresh and crispy, a nice cold dish because most are hot

PS. if you live close and aren't ready for the party atmosphere they also do to-go orders
author: danielle a.

description:
We have been wanting to go here for a while now and finally had the chance to late on Friday. The restaurant was nearly packed even when we arrived at 8pm. We were sat down at the bar - since it was the only area open - and it turned out great because we ended up having a waiter behind the counter for the entirety of the time (very fast service)! 

The music is loud and the restaurant itself is cozy - very millennial vibes. 

We ordered the following:
Chubby Kitty cocktail (not in my pictures - it was on the back of the menu): Refreshing, great with all the foods we ordered 
The Chubby Fried Chicken: a bit dry, but their coating and sauce was really good! 
The Szechuan Green Beans: delicious 
and The Garlic Noodles: a bit on the sweeter side but good none the less! 

I would go back here for a quick bite to eat to catch up with some friends!
author: Julia Y.

description:
Ugh, I was so excited to go to Chubby Noodle and try their delicious garlic noodle...only to be super disappointed. Everything was just so salty. Garlic? No, Salt. We added chicken into the noodles, and it was tasty but too expensive for a few pieces. 

Anyways, it sucked coming here. I was expecting good food, but this is a place that's more centered on tapas and drinks. So just come here for drinks.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
Me and a bunch of coworkers came here for a quick lunch. The food was A-OK. 

Chubby chicken - boneless - not my jam
Garlic noodles - tasty and wish I didn't have to share it
Green beans - standard stir fried kind, A-OK
Vermicelli - didn't like it, my coworkers finished that

Overall, it was a good break from the office. In and out in an hour!
author: Sam Y.

description: After eating here via Caviar, I finally got to dine in and Chubby Noodle gets a solid 5 stars. The garlic noodles are even better when dining in, and the same goes for their other popular dishes - Korean pork tacos, string beans, papaya salad, and more. I've only dined during lunch but would love to come for dinner and have some drinks as well. It's a small restaurant but worth the wait!
author: Edwina D.

description:
Came for dinner on a weekday with no wait! Chill, modern Asian fusion place that plays hip-hop/rap music. This place is awesome!!

The place itself is small, so I was really happy to come with no wait at 6:30 pm (there was a huge wait after we were done with dinner though)! 

Tried the 3 most popular things and recommended by my friends: spicy garlic noodles, szechuan green beans, and Korean pork tacos. The tacos were probably my favorite! The taco shell tasted more like a green onion pancake and the tacos itself was stuffed with lots of tender, juicy pork! A plate comes with only 2 tacos but my table was able to ask for 3 tacos since we had a table of 3. 

The spicy garlic noodles was sweet and spicy. If you can't handle spicy foods I wouldn't suggest getting this. Noodles were very soft, maybe slightly a bit too mushy. I would definitely add meat to it (I added the fried chicken) it makes it taste a lot better! The szechuan green beans were fried nicely, not overwhelmingly oily, and was a good combination of sweet and salty with a little spice. 

Waiters were super nice and kept asking how we liked our dishes and to refill our waters constantly. Would definitely come back to try more dishes and for bottomless mimosas!
author: Kelly H.

description:
Loved the garlic noodles. very chewy and satisfying.

Also got the curry vermicelli which had a great coconut curry flavor

Rib meat fell off the bone - great complement to the noodles

Probably wouldn't recommend the fried chicken.  Pretty plain in both flavoring and breading
author: Marshall Y.

description:
I did a bottomless brunch here with 5 other gals and we had a good time! The bottomless drinks and food is $45 which is a pretty decent price in the area. The drinks aren't anything special but they serve little duckies in them which is kind of cute albeit a bit kitschy. The strawberry mimosa definitely felt watered down so we asked for straight champagne. 

I didn't have high standards for the food but I was pleasantly surprised! The salt and pepper shrimp was super flavorful and the pork wontons were outstanding. I also loved the szechuan green beans and cucumber salad that we had as sides. The dan dan noodles were probably my favorite dish because they were sooooo good!

Overall, this is a fun place to come with friends and get a little loose. The music kind of makes it feel like a day club and it's definitely a younger crowd but it's a great start for day-drinking.
author: Megan K.

description:
my favorite spot in SF! great for dinner before a night out. most popular around 8PM. amazing amazing food, fun sake mixed drinks and tons of sake shots and beer. amazing music (think early 2000s, a millennial childhood soundtrack)
best orders: garlic noodles, green beans, cucumber salad, fried chicken
couldn't recommend this spot more! great for a group of friends. maybe come before 730PM if looking for a quieter dinner
author: Nazlee H.

description:
Nothing like masking the flavor of garlic noodles with jalapenos that do nothing for the dish, then allowing it to be served with tasteless fried chicken and calling it Asian fusion with a price to match. Absolutely shameful.

But the tacos were good.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
I first came to Chubby Noodle when they had their pop up store in some bar and loved the food immediately! I'm so glad they now have their own store not in one but two locations! 

My last visit here we ordered the pork tacos, Tuna poke with chips, pork ribs, spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken, beer and sake. 

Everything was based on the waitresses recommendation and everything was delicious. The service was terrific and food came out in a timely matter. The dishes are tapa style so there isn't much with each order, but the taste definitely makes up for it.

The place is rather small so if you have a large group it might be wise to make reservations.
author: Milton F.

description:
Fantastic Service By Danica! 

We walked in & the place was pretty busy but we received fantastic service from Danica! Our favorite dishes were the Salmon Sashimi (Must try!), Spicy Garlic Noodles and the Crispy Cauliflower. This was my first time visiting but the food was on point and the service was very welcoming! Will be back for sure
author: Jessica A.

description:
Got the Chicken Teriyaki from this place on Caviar tonight and it was not appetizing in the least. Even with all the Asian guilt I normally carry about finishing my food, I couldn't stomach having more than a couple of bites.

-The sauce was incredibly salty and ruined pretty much everything else: the rice was drenched in the sauce (note: soggy rice, ew), the veggies also inedible
-The chicken: mostly skin - the gross bumpy kind - covering a couple small pieces of reheated thigh

Maybe the food is better at the restaurant vs delivery, but I honestly can't imagine anyone who's ever had even greasy Chinese takeout finding this place remotely palatable.
author: Jen N.

description: Delicious, great service, very North Beach, local, music is a bit too loud..
author: Paul W.

description:
So have been staying local lately and decided that I wanted to hit up a brunch spot in the city on a Sunday. I had done a bit of searching and realized that this pop up had grown up with multiple locations in the city. I was a fan of the pop up so I did a deeper look and realized this place was an AYCE and AYCD brunch spot. Asian Fusion food that you can nonstop eat and nonstop drinks? Don't need to sell me any further. I made my way over to this spot around 15 minutes prior to opening to grab a spot in line. Parking is a bit challenging in the area so you will definitely want to bake in some time to secure a spot. There was a line that was forming by the time I reached the restaurant. The structure is essentially 90 minutes of eating and drinking and the joint packs all of its tables in this time fashion. If you miss the first wave, you have to wait till the next wave and it keeps going. 

The joint holds bar spots and tables for groups of people and the service moves quickly. The drinks are all poured into jugs and ready to be poured quickly. The servers move as quickly as the food comes out so there was constant movement. In the background you can hear the "clubbing" music which didn't quite fit the atmosphere but I did not mind. The one gripe I had with this spot is that, they recommend just eating whatever the kitchen prepares in batch otherwise if you want to order something specific, you may have to wait. In theory it makes sense but the reality of not being able to order and eat quickly and waiting for them to batch stuff was a bit of a "meh" factor for me. The price for this affair is $39 per person which is of course a great deal so that makes up some points. The menu of food offered 2 soups, 3 veggie options, 3 dumpling options, 3 dimsum options, and 3 noodle/rice options that you would receive in recycled order. During the time of being there, I was able to try the green beans, pork wontons, pork buns, salt and pepper shrimp, and the kung pao wings. All of the food was OK but this is certainly not authentic Asian food which you can get a mere few blocks away in china town. The food was either hit or miss for me personally with the stand out items being the wontons and the green beans while the others being OK. 

All in all, it is a fun atmosphere and certainly worth a visit if you are looking to just continue drinking and having some food while enjoying good conversation. If you are looking for straight up authentic Asian food or really focused on great food, this place may disappoint. Still worth checking out so give it a shot and make your own decision!
author: Dan M.

description:
This place is legit! The music is always great (a lot of hip hop, rap and other up-tempo music - there's a Spotify playlist), the food is incredible and the prices are very reasonable. Personal favorites are the string beans and spicy garlic noodles. 

I love bringing younger visitors here because it's always a good time. 

Only reasons I'm not giving 5 stars: there aren't many vegetarian options on the menu and the open kitchen often makes your hair and clothes smell like chubby noodle :)
author: Niyati D.

description:
Well, it's a bit different from the pop up that used to grace Amante's bar down the street.  Being on upper Grant Avenue, it is quiet during the day but probably a different story evenings.  We came for a late lunch on a recent Friday.  We waited at the greeting area and there were four occupied tables. My friend chose a wall booth which was a bit tight for my tummy.  After a quick study, here's what we over ordered:

Appetizers
1.  Chubby fried chicken (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=pm2jrEWjf1xca_BaK4YUGQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Served temperature hot, these boneless morsels went well with the provided aioli.

2.  Pork belly tacos (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Nlx0-2cAuakoxMzggmpuaQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - This was my friend's choice and, yes, this was good and hearty.  The pork was tender (pork belly?) and the flavors meshed well.

Mains
3.  Pad Thai (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=YvOKKHbh2ZmxD_4SEYQ15A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Hearty portions and the flavors were not bad, not quite as refreshing as I hoped.  

4.  Spicy garlic noodles with char siu (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=hUaTl8LpTo463X9kLP8sEg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Interesting rendition as the char siu was actually the traditional Chinese BBQ pork slices.  The spiciness came from white pepper which overwhelmed the garlic flavor.  Happy that the pork were lean slices.

Our waitress was efficient and pretty vanilla.  The food came out relatively quickly as the Pad Thai and tacos were the first to come out.  The menu is a little different from their original incarnation and it is definitely brighter here.  The food rates 3.5 stars with an additional half star for having food available lunch and dinner time.  The food definitely fits the bill as far as bar food as you'd likely want something (beer or sake) to wash it down.  If you're looking for finesse or culinary skills, this probably isn't a spot you should target.  The portions are generous are I ended up bringing home almost half of each of the mains as well as four or five chicken pieces.  Bring your appetite and temper your expectations.
author: Mike C.

description:
Had to wait a little bit for a two person table, the person seating us looked kind of out of it but caused us no problems.

We over ordered and didn't expect good portions but they were great, Garlic Noodles, Pad Thai, Fried chicken and the chicken wings. There wasn't that much choice from the offset, but all you ever really need is Garlic noodles and Fried chicken. Pretty sure every time I go there I won't feel bad about ordering the same thing over and over again.

Music was also banging. Good tunes
author: Terence T.

description:
I've meaning to try this place for the longest time and finally had the chance to a while back. I made the trek to North Beach with some colleagues of mine and we decided to get a number of dishes for the table.

We ordered the Spicy Garlic Noodles, the Curry Lemongrass Vermicelli, the Szechuan green beans, and Chubby Fried Chicken. Everything about this place is solid, from the food to the atmosphere to the service. There was virtually no wait during lunch time, plenty of seating! We were in and out in about an hour. 

The dishes are very shareable--it's much better to go with a group of people to get a taste of different dishes. There were four of us total and the amount of food was just enough to feel satisfied, but not enough to leave full.  Each of the dishes were very tasty. The garlic noodles had the perfect flavor combination of salty and garlicky. The vermicelli had just the right amount of spice and flavor. Same with the green beans, which were seasoned well. The chicken was my favorite. There was also a dipping sauce for the chicken, which complemented the chicken very well.

It came out to about 20 bucks a person, which is somewhat standard for an SF sit-down experience. I'd definitely come back again for that chicken. Solid spot in NB.
author: Meghan J.

description:
I really enjoyed this place.  We had a little scramble with our seats because the host was new and moved us 4 times.  The place is small, tables for 2 are way too small and too close together, booths are more comfortable and the community table should be used regardless of party size to avoid scrambling around and moving parties around.  Aside of that, the food was amazing and our server was great.  I loved the throwback music playing and the ambiance.

We ordered garlic noodles, Chubby fried chicken, salt and pepper shrimp and the green beans.  Everything was so delicious.  I will definitely come back.
author: Rachel L.

description:
First visit to this popular spot. I generally dislike anything labeled or described as "Asian fusion" because Asian food is awesome on its own and doesn't need to be messed with, especially when blending with western appetites just to appeal to North Americans.

Chubby noodle falls into this trap as well. Salt & pepper shrimp was average, chubby chicken no better than the average karaage from your local izakaya. The name is actually the same as chubby chicken from A&W (for you Canadians) which is actually just as good if not better. The pork tacos were good but the tortilla was super greasy and felt gross to the touch.

One exception, the uber popular garlic noodles were very tasty. Best dish we tried and even worth the trip just for that.

If you like Asian food, anywhere with sushi, pad Thai, fried rice and ramen on the same menu is a red flag. Asian restaurants should not try to replicate an airport food court in selection. Pick something and do it exceptionally better than anyone else.

Sake selection was pretty good for such a small spot (+1 star)
author: Pat K.

description:
A really fun place to go with a group. Very loud music, dont plan on talking much. I've been to both locations, and the North Beach location is now my favorite. It has more space, and the servers seemed way more attentive. 

Food was great! Make sure you come hungry. We ordered almost everything. But my favorites were the salt and pepper shrimp, chow mein, and tacos. 

The mimosas were made with some sort of pink juice, and I'm not sure how much alcohol is in them... But stick with Sapporo and you know what you're getting.
author: Katelyn S.

description:
Overall, everything was tasty. I would recommend this place if you are willing to spend $20+ to get full and don't mind waiting up to 1.5 hours to eat during peak times.

You have to order the ribs and string beans. Hands down best things I ate there. The ribs were warm, moist, and flavored well. A little bit of fat in each bite. However, the ribs were pretty small. I would say, on average, each rib had 2 to 3  bites.

The pork baos had great flavor. Love the mushrooms. Sweet and savory. 

The Korean pork tacos were subpar. However there was a good portion of meat on the dish.

I wouldn't order the Spicy Chili Garlic Noodles. Not too garlic-y. Definitely not spicy. The fried chicken add-on was more delicious than the noodles.

I also wouldn't order the coconut vermicelli noodles. They were overcooked and thus very soft and smushy. 

Interesting observation: Sake at the half carafe tasted better than the whole carafe.

Overall nice experience but not sure when I'll come again.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
This place is super fun with big groups and has delicious food!! The ambience is super fun and can be rowdy depending on what customers are there. 

Loved the spicy garlic noodles and fried chicken. You must order both. Pork tacos are also a must.
author: Sela B.

description:
Checked in for 12pm reservation about 15 minutes early and was told with a somewhat snarky tone that we would be seated at 12pm. Understandable but also a little confusing as the restaurant was completely empty at this point. I was standing inside by the door and the same man asked me to wait outside, again with the snarky attitude. The restaurant is small, but I was 1 person of a group of 7 standing in an empty restaurant, so I found this a little ridiculous. I've been here previously and have had people standing almost right against my table while I was dining as they were waiting to be seated - there must have been about 7 people waiting in the doorway/next to tables including my own and none of them were asked to "wait outside." 

I wouldn't return here with a large group - we were a party a 7 seated at a table that can only seat 6, but there was a larger table available for the entire time we were there. We were cramped, and while the food was great, not having wiggle room made this experience uncomfortable. At one point, the guy who checked me in came over with some orders and hastily moved drinking glasses out of the way, touching them at the rims, nearly spilling some, so he could practically drop the dishes on our table. Chubby Noodle offers a bottomless brunch/booze service - maybe larger tables should also be offered to accommodate such. 

All the other employees were great but this ONE was a sourpuss the entire time, at least towards our party. Having worked at a high volume restaurant that caters to hundreds of guests on a daily basis, I found his behavior completely  unacceptable. No one in our group did anything to deserve his attitude and we, as well as the majority (if not all) of your guests, were just trying to have a nice outing and enjoy good food.

Speaking of FOOD..

So GOOD:
Breakfast jook
Kung pao wings
Lemongrass chicken tacos
Hangover stew
Dan dan noodles
Chicken chow mein
Nanking eggplant
Szechuan green beans
Pork wontons

Just OK:
Rice cakes xo sauce
Salt & pepper shrimp
author: Krizia L.

description: Best spot in SF between the food, atmosphere and great music. If you're in the city you have to go to Chubby Noodle. Check out the garlic noodles with the chubby chicken
author: Alton B.

description:
Tried this place out for dinner on a Friday night. There was a ton of people and the expected wait was 35-45 mins, but turnover is pretty fast so I got in probably 20 mins in. 

The restaurant itself has a great vibe with cool decor and good music. It's a good place for small and large parties alike. The food was okay - I ordered the chubby fried chicken, spicy garlic noodles and BBQ pork fried rice. The spicy garlic noodles were really good and I definitely recommend that. The chicken was good but nothing special. Would skip the BBQ fried rice though. It was average at best and pricey for what it is. I also tried to the Sake flight and wasn't impressed with the selection. 

I would definitely like to try the place again and some of the other food, but for my first experience I wasn't impressed. They also offer a bottomless dim sum brunch by reservation which I am hoping to try.
author: Alvin N.

description:
This was probably one of our most disappointing experiences.  We stopped by there the night before and it was an hour wait.  With the great yelp reviews we figure it was a must try.  We went the next day (Sunday) and there was no wait at all.  

To start, we had the cauliflower, beer, and for the entree we went with the popular and recommended spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken and the shrimp.

The noodles were the biggest disappointment.  They were mushy, so perhaps overlooked, and the flavor was just Ok.  Chicken and shrimp were good but nothing special.

I would have given this place a third star, but they lose one because the waitress did not care enough to ask how the food was.  We ended up leaving most of the noodles and ate the rest.  

Won't be back and don't recommend.  I have to think the high ratings are not about the food, but I can see how it would be a cool place to hang out on a weekend, have beer with friends and  eat an ok meal.
author: Ibrahim M.

description: Came here for lunch, there were quite a few people ordering bright pink cocktails (the Chubby kitten?) I ordered the curry vermicelli noodles with chicken. Plenty large portion for one lady. This would be a great place to meet friends or have a day drink if you are so inclined.
author: Katherine S.

description: Recommend going on a weeknight and with a group no bigger than four since the place is pretty small. The cocktails are great! The spicy garlic noodles are a MUST, we added the Chubby chicken. Also ordered the pork fried rice, tacos and side of kimchi. For two, this was plenty of food, we had leftovers.
author: Melissa H.

description: Haven't visited SF in years so it was a treat to be back to the city by the bay. I usually visit a set itinerary of restaurants to soak in the tourist exodus gave but I skipped House of Prime Rib, Yellow Submarine, and 9th/Judah (Outer Sunset/UCSF) area in general for a new experience. I took my mom and sister to Coit tower so we decided to stay in the North Beach are and looked up a place to eat on Yelp. This place came up so we decided to give it a try. You really can't go wrong with cheese corn wings. Or tacos for that matter. Man we're we surprised. The food was great. If I wasn't so full I would have ordered another round of chips corn tacos. I should have skipped the beer. So you know the tacos had to. E good if I considered skipping the beer. The ch corn wings are a la Korean KFC so expect a little spicy and sweet. Finger licking good. The fat noodles were yummy as well. But the best part was listening to EZE and NWA pumped in through the sound system. Nothing but the basics and the better for it...Because it's all about the GTA.
author: Sam K.

description: I love Chubby Noodle.  I'm a huge fan and I always take my friends visiting the city to the Marina location.  This was my second time at the North Beach location and this experience was exactly the "Meh I've experienced better." that Yelp is offering to me.  My friends have never sent back a dish in their lives, but had to send back the Kobe beef chow mein.  They said it lacked any flavor and the beef was too dry, chewy, and sub-par to be called Kobe beef.  The server was nice about it and took it off the bill so we tipped her well as usual... My friend called me today and said he had AWFUL food poisoning :(   Really sucks to have your friends suffer at your favorite food place with only one day left in SF and now unable to stomach anything else.  I still love Chubby Noodle, but I'm sticking to the Marina location from now on.
author: Roxie S.

description: We made a reservation for 10 for AYCE and AYCD on a fine Sunday morning. We got there at 11am, were seated right away, and the clock was ticking. They give you exactly 1.5hrs to eat/drink, with strict rules on last call for both food and drink. For the AYCE the food was just okay, mediocre asian food - salt and pepper shrimp, garlic noodles, chubby fried chicken, peking duck buns, green beans, etc. There were 4 drinks on the menu, also just okay - pineapple mimosa, pink sangria, ginger sake cocktail, and sapporo. The service was 50/50 some of the waiters/waitresses were awesome - attentive and on point, others were kind of annoying and made it difficult to order what we wanted. Overall we had a great time, which was due to the AYCD, but the quality of the food and drink is just ok. Worth a try if you're looking for a good time, but not if you're looking for a quality AYCE experience.
author: Elaine N.

description:
We came here on a Saturday morning at 10:00 am.  We had reservations for 7 people and were seated immediately upon arrival.  Overall this place was excellent, we started with some green beans and, dumplings, pork bun, noodles and a few bowls.  The pork buns were by far my favorite, but all the food was excellent.  They serve unlimited rose and sangria drinks along with the meal.  They serve as much food as you want within the 90 minute time limit.  

The restaurant definitely has a unique serving process, one that I have not seen before, but it definitely works.  The atmosphere and vibe in the restaurant is awesome.  The music is awesome and definitely has a fun environment.  5 stars all around.
author: William F.

description:
Food: Half the menu is great, the other half is meh. Kale salad and pork buns were good, ramen was gross. 

Service: Really bad. Both times I've been there I had the same waitress and both times felt a very negative vibe. I've never had any issues with waiters or waitresses until eating here. I guess they're only nice if your in a group with a large tip amount. 

Ambiance: I love the interior, Hong Kong noodle house vibe. The music keeps the vibe upbeat and if you're with a group, a good place to eat before, during, or after drinking. Party vibes.
author: Kirk D.

description:
I've come here twice now and both times were delicious
The first time I came, I happened to come on Fat Tuesday; every Tuesday, their noodles are half portioned, half priced.  ordered:
Garlic Noodles + fried chicken
- The fried chicken was boneless and pretty good, but I'm not sure it was a necessary addition to the garlic noodles; the noodles would've been delicious on their own
Kobe beef noodles
- beef was tender and I liked the sauce
Korean tacos
- There were only 2 tacos but each bite was heavenly
The second time, I ordered the Curry Lemongrass Vermicelli
- Delicious! Not overwhelmingly saucey. I like the texture of vermicelli

Will come again!
author: Serena W.

description:
PAAAAAAAAAAASSSSSS.

$39 per person is a easy price to swallow if the service & food makes it worthwhile especially since the idea is AYCE, but honestly it was NOT worth the price or time to come here. Management is better off cancelling the AYCE option because clearly they do not know how to offer it.

I was part of a group of 13? 14? and we were here for my cousin's birthday to celebrate. Her boyfriend made reservations at 2pm and we were seated separately at 2 tables which wasn't a super big deal since my cousin just bounced between tables to chill with everybody. Right off the bat, our sever was just a huge turn off. They were not super friendly and drinks come through one at a time so you can't go wild. On the other hand, there was no limit to how much food you can order so we went for 2 orders of everything and the waitress that helped us said she put one order in first and that we'll get the 2nd order when everything goes through which sounded good. 

First 45-50 minutes was us sipping our drinks while seeing only about 3 plates of food come through. From a menu with 13 items. Wtf. The smaller groups around us were able to get way more food, way more variety than our big group was. With only 90 minutes to eat, this was not going the way any usual AYCE place was going. And I know the servers were frustrated with us, too, because we kept asking them to check on the food. You have to understand, your portions are small. I'm sitting at a table with 8 people and when food comes, it's gone immediately. Pork buns only comes in 3. Chicken wings came with 5. We're starving and we were already half way through our allotted time so that's bullshit. 

The group began asking any worker who came through to check on the food because it was ridiculous that it would take so long for food to come out especially for a place that does an all you can eat option. We even asked a busboy for help and we didn't know he was a busboy because there is no uniform here so all the workers are just dressed in normal clothing. Eventually our main server dude came back and told us the kitchen was swamped, that food should be out soon, and that we can't ask the busboy for help because and I quote, "they can't do anything." Well, shit. Then maybe you should come around more often than just staying away from us? Eventually it was last call and that was when the server came and asked if we wanted to order anything else before they were closing, but helloooo... we didn't even get half the food we ordered. The male server told us that the waitress in the beginning just gave us double portions of everything, but no way was any of the ones we received a "double portion." And if they were then I would hate to see how their regular portions were because it was skimpy af. 

Overall, this place really sucks. I'm not a mean person, I don't tend to grade hard at all, but this place really tested my patience. If you're going to do AYCE then please, prep yourself beforehand and anticipate a huge flow of people because for the price you're charging you need to be on top of your shit. Feeding everyone in the last 20 minutes before closing does not automatically make everything okay. And your servers, sure they started off nice but at the end, clearly we were all frustrated with how the day went.
author: Venus L.

description:
Very good flavors - fast service and pretty fairly priced. A modern play on classic Asian 'quick bites', seems to be the game here. With food selections ranging from Korean, to Chinese, to Thai & even some tacos on the menu .. it's a fun spot to eat and dine with friends. They have a good saké selection and some nice cocktails and beers available as well. It's been awhile since we're in this part of the city, or country for that matter - this was good. 

We had the spicy garlic noodles with char sui pork, pork steamed buns, & kimchi and marinated cucumbers. Quick late night fix before hitting some of the local watering holes. 

We would go again for sure! Thanks for having us :)

Happy Eating to you.
author: Ric H.

description:
If you're coming to Chubby Noodle for brunch, you really want to make sure you set up a reservation a week beforehand.  I've had a lot of good experiences at Chubby Noodle but to sum it up the drinks are bottomless and free and the food is average but amazing after you've had a couple.

For $40 a person for brunch and free drinks, it's a pretty good deal as long as you keep chugging mimosas.  In terms of drinks I really recommend the cold tea which is alcoholic jasmine tea.  For food, I recommend getting the salt & pepper shrimp and pork wontons.

You're going to want to sleep a lot after all the drinks you've had.
author: Mark C.

description:
Having missed the opportunity to dine at Chubby Noodle's pop-up on Green St., we heard that a permanent location opened on upper Grant Ave.  On a Friday, we decided to stop by for dinner before a show later in the evening.  At 6:30, the restaurant was quite full, but we were fortunate to be seated at a booth on the right side.  The restaurant has booths along the wall, tables in the middle of the floor with about eight bar seats. 

Checking out the menu, our waitress answered our questions and since it was our first time dining at here, she suggested some favorites.  With our suggestions in mind, we ordered:

Szechuan Green Beans - stirred fried with garlic, ginger and oyster sauce.  Tasty, but didn't find it special compared to what I what normally get from another restaurant serving this dish.

Spicy Garlic Noodles with Chubby fried chicken - egg noodles with garlic, cilantro and jalapeno.  For $5, we added the Chubby fried chicken to the dish. We requested that this not be made mild and they accommodated by not adding the jalapenos.  Six pieces of the boneless fried chicken were tossed with the noodles.  Very tasty noodle dish.

Korean Pork Tacos - tortillas with chili yogurt and cucumber.  Two tacos to the order. The pork was moist and tender and the chili yogurt complemented it well.

Tonkatsu Ramen - braised pork, egg, bamboo, scallions and nori in a pork broth.  Tasty pork broth with a perfectly cooked egg.  The braised pork was on the lean side, so it was not moist. 

We noticed that Chubby does a lot of take-out orders. The orders were constantly lining a side counter for delivery service pickups. Service was friendly, with advice for menu suggestions. The food was tasty and in general pretty good.  Service was friendly and appreciate our server for her suggestions.
author: Al L.

description: I came here on my first day in SF. The drinks are really good and strong. The Garlic noodles are a must have. However, the pork in the hot bun left much to be desired. I was very disappointed in this portion of the meal, it was pretty pricey to begin with but it was about half mushrooms and that is a shame. They could've used more pork especially for the price. Place was good but nothing special.
author: Abel A.

description:
Came here on a weekday night with a party of 3 because there was no wait.

All 3 of us ordered the Spicy Garlic Noodles and added the fried chicken. The noodles were yummy as they were saucy, had a nice kick, unique sweetness, chewy texture, and was full of garlicky goodness. The chicken however, I was not a fan of at all. The chicken was incorporated with the noodles and the breading was super soggy. I understand that it will loose its crispiness but it was soggy to the point the breading was mushing off. They also use white meat chunks and it was really dry. I found myself eating the noodles and avoiding the chicken that I paid an extra $5 for. 

Service was friendly but I don't think I will be returning.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I go to the North Beach location often with friends during the work week for a long lunch. It's always for a special-ish occasion since it's not a cheap place to go. It's always a great time though and their garlic noodles are a personal craving so this past weekend for my girlfriend's birthday we made a reservation for 7 to try their bottomless brunch menu. I feel like I should leave two separate reviews for Chubby, because our brunch experience a complete 180 from our regular experience.

Food - Good but less good than non-brunch menu. Not many vegetarian options for the vegetarian folks out there, although the kitchen did make a fresh plate of green beans without oyster sauce for my friend with food restrictions. So I guess the key is to just make a special request if you see something you want but can't have.
Drinks - Very watered downnnnn and slow refills.
Comfort - They sat 7 of us in a booth made for 4. That's 4 skinny people. We had to squeeze 6 of us in there plus a stool at the end. What?
Ambiance - Music was good but just way too loud to have any level of conversation.

As someone who has worked in the food service industry for over 10 years, I know how difficult it can be. The servers here were a disaster. It did not seem like any of them communicated at all in terms of who's role is to do what. It didn't seem like they had assigned tables either so oftentimes it took 5-10 mins to get anyone's attention. On top of that both food and drinks came out slow. It took some time for our servers to bring dishes out, certain orders were forgotten, and just a general vibe of unnecessary rudeness.

In my honest opinion, the brunch experience is not worth the $45. Our long lunches came out to maybe $40 a person with everyone leaving stuffed, buzzed and feeling happy. For the $60 total everyone spent this weekend, we each left Chubby Noodle feeling broke, cheated, and wanting more.
author: Nat E.

description:
I wanted to like this place soooo bad. My friend and I both had been hearing rave reviews from our other friends who brunch here regularly, and couldn't agree on a dinner spot the other night so thought we'd give it a go. I wanted ramen and she wanted chicken or something so we thought we'd split the difference. 

It was a Sunday around 7:45 and the place was pretty dead, so we sat ourselves and then asked for recommendations when the server came by. She recommended the spicy garlic noodles, the poke, the ramen, and a handful of other starters. We ordered the first 3 along with some kimchi. To say we were underwhelmed would be putting it nicely... the spicy "garlic" noodles tasted nothing like garlic but only like the large chunks of jalapeno in it, and the ramen was honestly...terrible. The broth tasted like dishwater and the noodles weren't fully cooked. My friend tasted it and agreed, and when the server noticed I wasn't eating it she said maybe someone new was cooking. Well, okay... 

She did ultimately take it off the bill at the end but the whole interaction was odd. The poke was great but it's honestly the only thing we ate and for a $60 dinner you could say we were pretty bummed. It's definitely a trendy vibe, they play rap music, dim the lights, and do a bottomless brunch, so I can imagine how that environment makes up for mediocre food if that's what you're into.
author: Lauren M.

description: Excellent food and service is friendly and quick. They aren't kidding when they say the spicy garlic noodles are spicy. The shrimp pad Thai was a great dish, and the chicken wings were also great. Would definitely recommend.
author: Chel H.

description: Big fan of garlic noodles, the was definitely the best I have had in the city. I would suggest adding chicken or some type of protein with it. Very good
author: Eva A.

description: The best noodle place in town. Start with the papaya salad and Szechuan green beans. The papaya salad is so so so good. A bit spicy, very herbaceous and good acid components. The green beans are the best, again a bit spicy but not overpowering. For dinner, I had the spicy garlic noodle with fried chicken. Omg. So delicious. For a noodle place, they make some of the best fried chicken. We also had the cauliflower and it was okay, probably wouldn't order it again. The atmosphere is awesome too. Gangster rap and a fun and lively environment. I hear the all you can eat and drink brunch on the weekend is a blast, I haven't been yet but just be aware they don't serve the full menu during brunch. Thanks Chubby Noodle for giving me my noodle fix!
author: Meghan G.

description:
A chill, hip, small, asian fusion restaurant.

Came here with 4 other friends because one of them really wanted to try it and made the reservation on a Saturday afternoon. Thank goodness she made the reservation because the wait outside was crazy. We were seated immediately and decided to go with AYCE and immediately started ordering dishes and drinks. AYCE was $39 a person but we felt like we would have went over if we didn't do it. We probably each got about 5 mimosas and sangrias. Pretty sure everyone in that restaurant was buzzed. The drinks each came with a duck in the drink which was pretty cute.The food came in decent sized plates and were pretty good for asian fusion cuisine. 

Some dishes that we got were: 
Szechuan green beans
Pork Buns
Kung Pao Wings
Chubby Chicken Chow Mein
Spicy Garlic Noodles
Jalapeno Calamari
Korean Pork Tacos

Service was not as bad as I would have imagined with AYCE places. The waitress was pretty accessible and came to refill waters, drinks, and took our order. The downside is that for a small restaurant they packed in the tables like sardines.

Overall, not a bad spot and a great place to try out!
author: Jeanette Q.

description:
Came here for the first time with five other people for brunch and even though my friends raved about the place I found it underwhelming especially for the price. I've been to many bottomless brunches where there were twice as many food and drink options as Chubby Noodle's. 

The drinks are weak. The sangrias and the mimosas both tasted like severely watered down juice. Despite the tea's serious ginger kick, that made up for the alcohol the other two drinks did not have. The food was average for what you'd expect Chinese food but no way would I pay a la carte prices for the equivalent of regular Chinese carry out. All in all, having had other bottomless brunches for the same price, you're better off getting your money's worth elsewhere.
author: Claire W.

description:
Basic people love brunch so consider me pH14. *insert pity laugh here for my chemistry joke*

For 39 dollars a person, you get a 90 minute session of all-you-can eat and drink from their menu. Not a bad bargain at all, especially considering the copious amounts of GOOD quality things you're going to voraciously devour.

My absolute favorite dish that I ordered three rounds of were the salt and pepper shrimp. They're seasoned beautifully and the sauce that is paired up with it is amazing! If you need to order a veggie dish to lessen your guilt, I highly recommend the green beans because they're so savory and delicious!

To wash it down, I found that their best drink on their menu that I had (read: multiple of) was the Nguyen-Nguyen mimosa. Super crisp, refreshing, light, and will definitely hit you like a truck while you're trying to keep it cool while headed to the airport right after brunch.
author: Jonathan N.

description: Had doubts but the noods were great.
author: Kelly G.

description:
It's simply not worth it! Not worth the hype, not worth the money, and not worth for the long wait! My group ordered the AYCE brunch which is $45 per person including unlimited drinks. They served you three dishes at a time throughout the course of two hours (be mindful there's time limited for this, I believe it's two hours more or less) and they constantly refilled your drink (very attentive). However, the food here was just below average and we didn't expect to get the Panda Express fast food kind of meal for $60/person. Also the mimosa gave us bad headache afterward. 

Overall, ambiance is great for group. It's just not worth to pay $60 including tips.  I'd recommend Pink Elephant instead of here.
author: Kandice Z.

description:
I'm actually really surprised that I like this place as much as I do. I must have been the company, because our server was high AF. no, seriously -
 He was slurring his words, forgetting our order and shattered a glass with the pieces falling all over my friend. 

I wished they gave us a discount, but they just gave us sake shots. 

Here's what we ordered:
- gigantic bottle of sake that serves 10 people, but there was only 4 of us
- garlic noodles
- string beans
- fried rice
- fried chicken
- pork tacos
- salt and pepper shrimp

My favorite were garlic noodles (watch out for your breath after), string beans and the salt and pepper shrimp!

It's a fun place, but make sure you make reservations if possible. and watch out for the stoned servers.
author: Andy H.

description: SO, came here with a group of friends. We were pretty pumped because this place has gotten a big hype lately and we made reservations a few weeks in advance. We get there, the decor is legit. The waiters come by and let us know how it works, which is all you can eat and drink within two hours, and they will bring out almost one of everything on the menu. They then take our drink orders, we all get either the watermelon mimosa or the sangria. It was watered down AF. They keep ice in the pitchers that they are walking around and serving with, so you just get a bunch of watered down juice pretty much. A little disappointing, BUT NO WORRIES, we are laid back. We understand you gotta hustle peeps somehow when you are serving all you can eat and drink, right? So we all switched to Sapporo, no big deal. Still loving life. Then the food starts to come out and its pretty good. I liked the Chicken Chow Mein. The servers were attentive, but SASSY with a capital ASS. Reminded me of Illana and Ru in that one episode of Broad City. Fine, again no big deal, its the city, I'm used to it. So life was dandy, and then we get the salt and pepper shrimp. There was this huge piece of what looked like white fish underneath all of the fried shrimp. All of us were hesitant to eat it, but I jokingly tell my husband to just put it in his mouth. So he does. AND ITS A RAW CHICKEN WING. He ate a piece of raw chicken wing. We ask the server if this was intentionally put on the plate and he apologizes and says no and takes it to the back of the house. We ate all that shrimp that was on top of the raw chicken wing, so we were nervous. The server comes back with NEW salt and pepper shrimp, like here betches ALL FIXED. I didn't want to eat anything else. I was waiting for Gordon Ramsey to come save me and close the damn kitchen. I asked the server how this raw piece of chicken got mixed in with the shrimp and he explained how they bread the wings and shrimp at the same flour station and it somehow ended up on our plate. I get it, but also HOW? So I was like... sir, are we going to get sick? And he was like not unless you ate it... and my husband was like, uhhhh I ate it. And the server puts a hand on his shoulder and says, "Well, good luck buddy." And walked away. We still paid over $50 each for our meal. AND all six of us were all shitting our brains out later. THANKS CHUBBY NOODLE. Broke my damn heart. And toilet
author: Lauren M.

description:
Honestly, this was the worst service I've ever had in my life tonight. The restaurant was practically empty, with one other party seated, and I was waiting on two friends to come because my friend from San Jose wanted to eat here for his birthday. The guy at the bar said that I could sit down, and I said that my friends would be there 5-10 mins later, which he said was fine. Then 7 mins later, this rude waitress comes to me and tells me that "we don't seat incomplete parties", and we have people with reservations, so if your friends don't come in the next 5 mins, you're going to have to leave. I was already waiting there, drinking water, and I even told the guy who said I can sit that I was waiting on friends to come. Then after 10 mins, I caught the waitress's attention. She looked at her watch, and I asked the waitress if I can order.She promptly said, "are they coming soon?" and I said one is on a Lyft here, while the other was on the way, and it was his birthday so 5-10 more mins. She told me to just wait till my friends come to order because the food comes out really fast, but she was just giving me dirty looks the whole time and throughout the night. When my friends finally arrived 25 mins after I had been waiting, we saw her whisper to another waiter while pointing at us. The whole time we were eating, I felt uncomfortable and bad vibes, and wanted to leave asap. I would look up at times and would see her giving looks and it was not only me that noticed, but my friend as well. 

I understand if she would have wanted me to leave if there was a) people waiting for a table or b) an actual reservation because in the whole time I was waiting maybe two or three more tables were seated, with four empty tables by the window, and one empty one by the side. But, there was no one waiting outside, no other parties coming, so I don't see what the problem was when I did have the intent to eat here and my friends were on the way, but were delayed due to traffic. It was my friend's birthday so I didn't want to argue, I didn't give attitude back or talk to the manager about how rudely we were treated. 

If you are a restaurant that is half empty, wouldn't you want customers to sit in? Your customers are the reason why your business is here, so I don't appreciate restaurants with rude employees. I'm never coming back here as the food was subpar, as it was nothing special, with small portions, and terrible customer service. That's no way to treat your customers, and I can't support any business that would make their customers feel so uncomfortable while eating by giving looks and practically kicking them out when there are available seats.

Also, when my friend checked his bank statement, the transaction showed that they had changed the overall amount, by giving themselves more tips. Save yourselves the trouble and just eat elsewhere in North Beach.
author: C H.

description:
Just the best fried chicken in the world!!!!
We had the Szechuan green beans, Korean pork tacos, cucumber salad, and the curry lemongrass vermicelli. EVERYTHING was great!
author: Pedro L.

description:
Love love love Chubby Noodle for a great trendy dinner spot. There are two locations in San Francisco and both are great. This location is definitely easier to get a reservation at, particularly for a large group. Love the cocktails and drink selection. For food, you can't go wrong, but definitely try the below:
* Spicy Garlic Noodles
* BBQ Fried Rice
* Korean Pork Tacos!!!!
* Salt & Pepper Shrimp
* Chubby Fried Chicken
author: Carol Ann V.

description: Loved the Szechuan green beans. Is it a place I could rave about to a friend ? Mmm, probably not. The music was too loud to really have a conversation and the wait staff seemed just pleasant enough to get by. Decent food, but not anything to write home about.
author: Vanessa G.

description:
Now I want to move to San Francisco. I mean, I love SF for many reasons, but Chubby Noodles is near the top. A fellow Texan urged us to visit on our trip last week and we were blown away!  The Tuna Poke was near perfect and the fried chicken was thoroughly enjoyed. That being said, it is the Spicy Garlic Noodles that I will miss most. Please Chubby Noodle, can you open a branch in Dallas?  

They were already out of wings and ribs when we got there...I hear they are legendary. Next time I'm in town, you can find me at Chubby Noodle!
author: Diana D.

description:
Sunday brunch with the girls 

Popular spot that gets packed quickly. Theres a line that develops about 10-15 min before it opens so give yourself time to find parking and hop in line. 

$39 /pp Sunday brunch which includes mimosa or sangria. 
Food was ok, portions where good, music and atmosphere were great. 
 
Scratching this place off my list. Over all- great place to meet friends and grab a bite if youre in the area looking to try the asian tapa / dimsum with a bit of artsy city mixed in it. It wasn't over the top great but dont let my taste buds be the final judge.
author: Marlee B.

description:
We heard about this place being famous for their garlic noodles and oh my gosh they were no joke. The menu is very small and they have a nice alcohol menu. We ended up just ordering the garlic noodles with fried chicken and it was SO good!! 

The only strange thing about this was I saw no warning about the crazy loud rap music. I'm not opposed but it was very surprising to hear how loud it was when we walked in. For a tiny place the high volume isn't really that necessary. Would visit again though!
author: Sara L.

description:
Walking through the streets of San Fran searching for food the this place caught my attention. From the old school diner feel with low lighting and rap music, who wouldn't want to stop here? 

I ordered the spicy garlic noodles and I am kicking myself for not going a second time before heading back to the Midwest. Hands down the best noodles I've had yet. 

Why oh why do we not have a chubby noodle in Midwest?!
author: Courtney B.

description: One of the first places I ate at when moving to SF as. All I can say is, simply amazing! The chicken "nuggets" are so good!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Finally made it to Chubby Noodle after wanting to try their bottomless brunch for a couple of years. It lived up to the hype! We came here on a Sunday afternoon with a large group towards the end of service and the staff were accommodating and friendly despite being a bit passive aggressive initially (I can't blame em). We had a few vegetarians and they were able to modify some dishes for us which was super nice. Service was fast and frequent which is the key to a happy bottomless meal experience :).

The food itself was delicious. The endless mimosas and the constant stream of food made it hard to keep track of what I had and hadn't eaten so I ended up just eating whatever got put in front of me and I enjoyed it all! I especially liked the duck, the bok choy, and the noodle dishes. I'll definitely be back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Dennis C.

description:
I ordered 4 things via caviar: garlic noodles, papaya salad, green beans, and steamed pork buns. When my order got here, my garlic noodles were missing. I called chubby noodle 3 TIMES within 45 minutes and the moron, Isaac, who answered the phone must have been high bc all he could say was, "I can give you the number to caviar support and you can try calling them." I shouldn't have to call the restaurant 3 times to fix THEIR mistake. In the 3 years of living in SF, I have never experienced such shitty customer service. 

Update: it has been over 1.5 hours and I still don't have my fucking garlic noodles

@ chubby noodle management - fire Isaac, he's a fucking moron
author: Lindsay Q.

description:
**Brunch Review**

Food: Being picky, most of the dishes (I ordered one of everything) were a little too saucy/salty and some of the dishes started blending in together (all of that soy sauce). Overall, food was pretty food, and off the brunch menu, green beans and salt and pepper shrimp were my favorite. The jook and bok choy and mushrooms were good in an understated sort of way. 

Drinks: Nothing to write home about (my preference was the sangria) but they were all.... very drinkable and constantly flowing.

Service: Fantastic, efficient, and easygoing

Overall a good and fun experience. $50 is a bit pricey for brunch....... but it's San Francisco, the food is good, and just drink your moneys worth... but keep it together.

Tip: Plan your pee breaks accordingly, there is one bathroom.
author: Trang B.

description:
Finally got to do the AYCE brunch last Sunday - on the weekends Chubby Noodle does all you can eat and drink for $37/pp. You can order as many dishes as you want from their brunch menu, and you can drink as much as you want from the included drinks. These include a sangria, a mimosa, or a beer (at our time it was Sapporo).

We made reservations for 10:30 am (first reservation slot of the morning), but there weren't a lot of people when we came. To make reservations, you have to call in since they have a 90 minute limit for dining AYCE, so their reservations follow a schedule. Once seated our drink orders were taken - I went for the orange juice mimosa while my friend went for the cranberry sangria. Both drinks came decorated with a rubber ducky and gave us a good buzz during our meal. Luckily with all you can drink we were also able to stuff ourselves with the following dishes:
