description: Chubby Noodle is my favorite restaurant in SF! Their brunch is the best! If you're trying to eat a ton of delicious food and drink a bunch of good drank chubby noodle is the spot!! The North Beach location is the best! The service is always incredible and the music is on point (hip hop nation fo life). They can take any size party but reservations are crucial. I've tried everything on the menu and it's great, chubby noodle I love you
author: Jorgen A.

description: ehh.. I went here for dinner, it didn't seem anything special to me. The food was decent, service was a bit slower. But nothing that made me really excited to go back. There was just something missing for me here. The one thing I got was the korean pork tacos, great presentation. Again there was just something missing for me.
author: Jessenotpatrick D.

description:
Love the food here! It's great for groups around 4-6. Had a great vibe. One of my go to places for dinner and drinks. 
Love the pork tacos, love the garlic noodles and chubby fried chicken. 

They also a do a great duck wrap special. Poke is good as well. 

I recommend eating here if you haven't had it. 

They're also available on caviar in any case you're to comfortable to leave your home.
author: Paolo M.

description:
Chubby hand roll - 3/5
Spicy garlic noodles + fried chicken - 4/5
Pork belly yakitori - 2/5 - Overcooked
Duck bao - 3/5
Combo rice - 2/5

Overall, 3/5
author: Mark O.

description: With only one or may be questionably two dim sum items you are really offering a sad excuse for a "bottomless" dim sum + drinks  menu. I gave you 5 stars because you had the honesty to mention fisting on the top of your menu what describes pretty accurately the whole brunching  experience.
author: fabrice a.

description:
I'm really surprised it even has 4 stars.... This is the worst experience/food I've tasted. I was so excited to try the North Beach location but I must say, it doesn't compare to the Marina location. If you had to pick between them, definitely try the Marina location cause it's always consistent and service is wayyy better and the food especially. 

We got sated down, and the we ordered our first couple dishes for brunch ($35 + gratuity + all you can drink mimosas, beer, and sangria NOT including cold sake and some other drinks). It service was horrible and took forever. We had to wait at least 10 mins to order the next round, the drinks tasted horrible especially the mimosas. The food was greasy, it didn't taste good OR even fresh. 

I will never come to this location -- Marina is the way to go. Sorry North Beach. You disappointed me and I will never recommend this location.
author: Jenn L.

description:
This review is for the unlimited brunch, $37 for unlimited small plates and drinks, with tax and tip around $50 per person. 2 stars: I had a negative experience and I'd rather not go back.

I thought the restaurant did not deliver on speed of service. Multiple staff persons delivered food, but only one person in the entire restaurant could take new food orders. Our table was next to the computer where the staff could enter orders, so we thought it would be easy. Instead, we waited more than 10 minutes for the staff person to come around, and even when they saw us, they didn't stop by. The poor person was trying to take orders for the entire restaurant and it wasn't going well.

The food was actually fairly decent. Pork buns, pickled vegetables, and stir-fry noodles. Avoid the porridge. It was too salty. But, the speed of food was quite variable. The steamed pork buns came out very fast. But string beans never came out. My group ordered them when we sat down. We asked for them 3 times over the course of an hour, and they never arrived.

For drinks, I think some of us managed to get 4 mimosa or sangria orders over the 90 minute time limit. That is decent for the price but I still think it was not a good value.

For a $50 (after tip and tax) brunch that we made reservations for, I expected more. The food was good but I thought the execution was lacking. I am not coming back for brunch.
author: Miguel C.

description:
When my friend told me about an all-you-can-eat dim sum place, I was immediately sold! So we went with a party of 6. All you can eat dim sum with bottomless mimosa & sangrias for $37 (not including tax & tip) for 90 minutes. I think we ended up ordering everything on the menu expect for dumplings because they didn't have any.

The "Hoang" Mimosa - I had 2 cups. This was good but it was a little diluted for me.

I ranked the following dishes in the order of what I liked the best to least:

Good:
1. Peking Duck Steam Bun - This is honestly the best dish on their menu. Please give this a try.
2. Steamed Pork Buns - This is the second best dish on their menu. Please also give this a try.
3. Breakfast Jook - Egg & bacon makes everything taste good.
4. Garlic Green Beans - Garlic + Oyster sauce = Heaven in my mouth
5. Boy Choy & Mushrooms - I'm usually not a fan of boy choy but this was seasoned really well.

Decent:
1. Chubby Chicken Chow Mein 
2. Shrimp Fried Rice
3. Salt & Pepper Shrimp
4. Pork Wontons
5. Chilled Ramen - There weren't enough noodles to split between 6 people.
6. Kung Pao Wings

Bad:
1. Sezchaun Shrimp & Pork Soup - This is gross; don't order it.

Didn't try:
1. Shanghai Dumplings
2. Orange Salad

Notes: This isn't an authentic dim sum restaurant but some of the dishes taste pretty similar to the ones at an authentic dim sum restaurant. This restaurant is located in North Beach so parking is impossible. It's a small restaurant so make sure you come early for a table. I would say a party of 8 is the maximum for groups. The booths can fit 6 people, but it's kind of a tight fit. There needs to be more table space. There were a few dishes that took a while to come out. So we ended up eating everything off the menu in 90 minutes. We did have two rounds of the salt & pepper shrimp, but that was it. They blast really loud hip hop music. I don't think it suits the atmosphere of a dim sum brunch place. It feels more like you're at a club haha. I do wish that they had serve tea here. The service was great. With tax & tip, it was about $48/person. I personally wouldn't want to spend another $48 on brunch because I can't eat much for my first meal of the day. Overall, this was a good experience. Definitely a trendy spot for someone who's willing to spend a little extra on a fusion dim sum brunch restaurant.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
Came here with my family to celebrate my birthday. My sister made reservation for 9 people at 6:30 PM. My sister stated that the hostess will give away our table if we do not have 90% of our party here. I did not like how they will give away someone's reservation; what is the purpose of having reservation if they can give it away?????? We had 7 people, so they sat us down. The hostess or server lady wasn't that friendly, she was being pushy and was not patient enough to let us look at the menu. We sat down for 2 min, and she came here to take our order already.......what is the rush? Not sure about their customer service here. 

The restaurant is clean, trendy, and has a modern rustic feel to it. The restaurant is small, so it is not good for large group. The music in here was so loud, it was hard to conversate with my family. Not good for family style - food was small portion. The food comes out very fast - maybe it was pre-made already?? Overpriced Asian fusion food. 

Food:
-Steam Buns: 4/5. It contains shredded pork, napa cabbage, hoisin sauce, shitake mushroom, and Thai chilli. The bun was very soft and moist. I mostly tasted the hoisin sauce, could not taste any thai chilli. Overall it was pretty good, maybe less hoisin sauce would be better. 

-Spicy Garlic Noodles w/ roasted chicken: 3/5. It was meh. I could not taste any garlic at all. It was really peppery, that's what I mostly can taste.  

-Kobe Beef Chow Mein: 3/5. There is barely any BEEF in this chow mein. There  were probably like 3 piece of beef in the noodle. I want more meat in this!!!! 

-Tonkatsu Ramen: 2/5. Saw review raving about the ramen. Not sure how is it good??? I had better tonkatsu ramen than here. Small portion, and my egg was not fully cooked - the egg white was still jelly. The soup does not taste like pork bone broth, taste like water.

- Peking Duck Wrap: 4/5. It comes with lettuce, carrots, and cucumber. The peking duck was stir fired on a hot plate with chili pepper. The dipping sauce was good - I believed it is fish sauce, chilli flakes, garlic, and ginger. I don't think they roast the duck themselves, maybe a store bought peking duck.
author: May H.

description:
Got the bottomless drinks and food with some friends over Halloweekend. Chubby was bumpin' music the whole time and the waiters were dressed in costumes. Def a fun spot to kick it, but I'm not the biggest fan of the food. Some of it was good (like and Pepper Shrimp), but other food (like the pork buns) were not that great. 

The bottomless drinks and food is $37 + tax & tip. There's a 90 minutes time limit, but it's unlimited eats and drinks, as the name suggests haha. One beef I had with this is that there's no option to remove the drinks pairing from the food. I wasn't planning to drink, but ended up getting charged for drink and food (despite no drinking as I had planned). Other than that, it's not a bad deal, but the food quality could be better (read: more authentic). I'm not the biggest fan of Americanized Asian food, which is the best way to summarize the type of food at Chubby.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
First timer, we went here on a Saturday night around 7pm. There wasn't a wait which was great, we were seated right away and the hostess was really nice to explain to us about the menu. But after given the menu we waited for anyone to come by to take our order and no one came. A server kept going around us and going to the tables next to us. We were obviously ready to order and she looked at us a couple of times but never came. I waited again for her to walk by and she went straight to the table next to us, she looked at me and I made a sign that we were ready and she just walked away. So I decided to follow her to the bar and ask if where we could put in our order and told me she can get it on our table but, since I was there I just told her that I can tell her there since we were already talking.
Our order came out pretty fast. We got the fried chicken and the pad thai.
I really enjoyed the chicken and the sauce. It was flavorful and has a bit of a kick.
The pad thai though, to me, has a thicker sauce than usual or I'm used to. It almost has the thickness of a spaghetti sauce. The flavor of the pad thai was good but it didn't taste authentic. I've been to a lot of thai restaurants some better than others and you can tell if it tastes like what it suppose to or not. The pad thai here was good but it tasted very "americanize," if that makes sense.
Our experience over all was good but nothing special. 
Maybe, next time we visit we can try more things on the menu. I'm willing to give this place another try.
author: N D.

description:
Chubby is definitely a must try! Didn't expect that a spontaneous dinner here while waiting for my laundry to finish would be so delicious. 

Service was excellent and price is definitely reasonable for the portion and taste! The food was unique and very creative! A delicious asian fusion food corner!

My orders were: 
SPICY GARLIC NOODLE - 4/5 - Don't expect Crustacean's (aka An's garlic noodle), but it was still tasty and full of flavor! 

KOREAN PORK TACOS - 4/5 - Yummy and unique! 

CHUBBY FRIED CHICKEN - 4/5 - Not a fan of fried chicken, but this one was an exception. The skin was crispy and not oily... plus no bones, so dig in! Eat in moderation though!

SALT AND PEPPER SHRIMP - 3/5 - Delicious but typical. 

SZECHUAN GREEN BEANS - 5/5 - Love it! A combination of szechuan and korean (perhaps?).  

SIZZLING FISH - 3/5 - It was my least favorite of all but it was still yummy!
author: Sharlene P.

description:
Normally I would give this place a 9/10... but it is 4/20, and I am in pain.  With all due respect to the chefs of this establishment, I'm so fucking pissed right now. Let me set the scene: 

It's April 20, 2017 and after a long day of work, I poured myself a robust glass of Pinot Noir and smoked a blunt with my friends. 

Upon realizing I was hungry... I did what any Normal person would do and ordered myself some grub. After browsing through the Postmates options, I settled myself on an old and trusty fave. 

40 minutes later my delicious food arrived: pork tacos, spicy garlic noodles, and cucumber salad, a recipe for success. First dug into the tacos, which seemed like the best fit for an appetizer. Great choice because it was delicious. Next I settled in for some spicy garlic noodles. And that's when things went wrong. 

HOLY FUCK - these noodles were en fuego. Now I'm not the kind of person who can't handle her heat, I usually add hot sauce to "spicy" foods. And I've had these spicy noodles many times before. But for some god forsaken reason, the garlic noodle to jalepeño slice ration was about 5:1. I mean astronomical amount of jalepeños. These noodles are so fucking hot I can't eat more than four bites without tearing up.  I'm literally writing this review during a noodle eating break. And my eyelids are sweating. 

This seems like a good time to remind you that it's 4/20. Have you ever experienced the cruel cruel scenario of wanting something so badly that's right in front of you... but you know it's bad for you? Well that's me right now with these fucking noodles. 

Time to get myself some lip balm and a glass of water and sack up. It's worth it. 

Overall, chubby noodle ... 9/10.
author: Madelaine R.

description:
Ordered a Pad Thai and a fried chicken pieces from Amazon Now. It was delivered in 38 minutes flat! Impressive. The food was fresh, hot and delicious. The dipping sauce was tasty, and it was certainly enough food for 2 people. 

I would likely order again.
author: Jordan C.

description:
#tl;dr Can't go wrong with any of their 3 spots, but Marina's my fave with this & Green St tied for 2nd depending on which is closer / open / less packed when hanger strikes.

I'm going to stop calling it North Beach and call it Nerd Beach from now on. #neeeardebeeech #boiiiii At Giormario Bros, I got into an HP Lovecraft talk w bartenderbro; here at Yubb Yood I ran into a video game connoisseur. I can at least take comfort knowing this hood isn't raising my hipster quotient.

(-_^) Duck Buns #simulsoftxcrisp #twss
(-_^) Duck Jook #wbacon
(-_^) Daily Ceviche #colorfulpuffchips
(-_-) Fried Chicken #bromeydontplaydat

My only real "issue" was they kept playing the parental advisory explicit lyrics music while a mom & kid were dining. I'd heard #rip Michael Jackson cut on then cut off real quick, so I know they can choose what plays. I understand this venue isn't aimed at kids & vulgarity doesn't bother everyone, but still.

No oysters when I went, but their common selection is Miyagi #basic and St. Simon, flexopen per market availability. TBD if they'll do HH or $1 oysters. Don't act like you didn't think I'd inquire. #doyouevendollaroystersbro

CURRENT INFO
(415) 296-9600 straight to voicemail for now
Tue-Sat 5:30pm-11:00pm
Closed Sun & Mon
author: Dan B.

description:
I am glad I was suggested to visit Chubby Noodle. I was greeted with excitement and hospitality. The music is fun, energetic and loud. If you aren't into a fun dinner atmosphere, look elsewhere bc this place is absolutely different in that sense!

Went with my daughter and her boyfriend. My daughter was dancing the entire time and even busted a move with their managers, Enrique and Stephen. Great and very sweet gentlemen!

The food was delicious. SO TASTY! Every bite left me wanting more. 
-Spicy garlic noodles--creamy-like sauce, a jazz of scallion and parsley. Simple yet so much taste!
-korean pork tacos--we ended up getting 2 orders of that bc it was SO good. It comes with 3 so each of us were sure to have two. I have NEVER had tacos with korean pork, cucumber and whatever else they put in it...wow.
-Fried rice-- so I am full blooded filipino so I know good fried rice when I get it. I am always nervous when ordering fried rice but felt confident since the other dishes blew my mind. Got the rice and was correct, phenomenal. I almost got an order TO GO home with for later!
-orange salad--really zesty and clean the palate. mixed greens, bean sprouts, oranges, walnuts. A really nice salad!

Wish I had more room to keep chowing down on their menu. I loved every bite and wish I lived in SF so I can try all the dishes. The menu is truly INNOVATIVE, different and a lot of variety! I HIGHLY recommend this spot.

Thanks for the fun experience Chubby Noodle! I will see you soon.
author: Bernie H.

description: After arriving in SF, we had a delicious meal here. Even though it was pretty filled for lunch, we scored a table by the window. Service was quick and friendly and the playlist was awesome. Everything we ordered was pretty good but my favorite was the spicy garlic noodles.
author: Cindy B.

description:
Excellent food!  Portions are large.  I had spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken (hell yeah!).  Could only manage two-and-a-half Korean tacos before I had to throw in the towel.  Mexican Coke in a bottle was the best pairing with the garlic noodles and jalapeños.

Parking is on-street, metered.  Some is 30-minute.  You may have to circle a few times, or park a couple of blocks away.  They close from 2:30-5:30, so plan accordingly.

The target demographic is twenty-somethings.  Music is loud with explicit lyrics and overly boomy bass.  Pop-hip-hop, with mother-truckers for effect.  My kids giggle and blush at West Side Connection, so whatever they were playing wasn't offensive.  We were just happy to get such great food before the kitchen closed.

Don't be afraid to get too much food.  The garlic noodles and pad thai would make excellent leftovers.

There is a single clean bathroom in the back.

Would definitely recommend to anyone.
author: Al L.

description:
Came here during the craziness of the North beach street fair.

Small location, with a few booths and several smaller tables. Definitely not a place for "private" conversations. Make sure you don't mind loud music and touching elbows with your neighbors :)

I would say Chubby noodle is definitely a place for drinking (lots of sake and beer) and socializing with friends over some tasty bar food. Overall, the meal was good, but not amazing. Tastewise, flavors are definitely more catered toward... non-traditional asian tastebuds. Food here is not authentically asian and most definitely more "fusion" as the descriptions say. 

My friend and I shared the following:
Spicy green beans: great flavor, spicy, mediocre portion, but overall good char on the bans
Pork Ribs: I would say the sauce is more on the tangy side..probably a bit too tangy for my taste, would've appreciated a bit more sweetness to be added mixed in with the vinegar. Though it was tender and fell off the bone.
Chubby chicken - Reminded me of chicken tenders.. yea nothing special.

Drinks: 
dont get the jose rose sangria...it taste like water.

Overall i would recommend this place for socialization and less for the food. The food is definitely "trendy" and the atmosphere is "fun". I wouldn't come here for amazing dining experience though. Probably find better choices and selections at a local mom and pop asian shop.
author: Diane T.

description: My husband and I went here for dinner while in SF. The bbq pork fried rice was delicious. It was perfect. We also had the Kung pao chicken wings and they were awesome. Flavorful food. Well be sure to go again when we are in SF.
author: Julie B.

description:
Um. Wow. I am shocked I had never visited Chubby Noodle before I recently did. This place is excellent--put it on your "can't miss" list for SF.

Location/Atmosphere: 3/5. A little crowded and cramped. It was loud inside and super busy--the tables are very close together. No idea what their Marina location is like, so I can't compare. But the Chubby Noodle definitely has a casual vibe because of how cramped the inside is, which doesn't quite match with the price point.

Service: 4/5. I definitely recommend calling ahead to make a reservation. When we arrived at 7 pm on a rainy weeknight, the restaurant was packed with a line. We were very thankful that we *had* called ahead. The food and drink service is quick--we never had to wait more than 10 minutes for anything. But again, because of how bustling and hectic the inside is, if we wanted to add to our order, it was difficult to flag down our server.

Food and Drink: 5/5. So um, WHO CARES ABOUT ANYTHING I SAID ABOVE? Me actually. Usually I do. Usually I am a huge snob for places with the right atmosphere, and if the service peeves me off even a tiny bit, I'm all "no way man, you lose a star for that, this is San Francisco, we deserve more." But you know what? I'm willing to let all of that slide for Chubby Noodle because the food was that damn good. My favorite was the pork tacos--I know it's not a traditional taco, but WOW. Also try the pork buns, ribs, chicken, and the spicy garlic noodle. Everything we had--literally everything--was amazing. But those tacos...!

Overall: Rise up above your restaurant snobbery, make a reservation at Chubby Noodle, and please try the tacos.
author: Kate T.

description: Took 30 min to put my name in. Then they forgot about us. The hostess lady was serving too???? Maybe focus on one job at a time first. First impression makes a difference.
author: Billy L.

description: This was my first stop after landing in SF. My friend and I were going to go somewhere else but I'm so glad we decided to come in here instead. It's a pretty lively place. Music is kind of loud and it's hard to hear one another but I enjoyed the atmosphere. My friend and I decided on the garlic noodles and schezwan green beans. Both dish were so yummy and flavorful! Kind of sad to see it end. The staff were all really friendly! Kind of sad I didn't go back before I left but I'll be back for them in May!
author: Linh N.

description:
Inside joke: the wifey and me kept referring to this place as the Chubby Bunny, I don't know, we're complete dorks. It sounded funnier for some reason. 

Anyway, we were staying in our hotel and were feeling a little lazy so we decided on ordering some food through DoorDash since the wifey had a free delivery code. Once we noticed Poke on the menu, we were down. We agreed on the poke, fried chicken, and Kobe beef noodles. 
SO FRIGGIN' GOOD. Yeah, the amount of poke was unfortunate but hella fresh and tasty. Those kobe beef noodles though. I'm drooling just typing this up. My favorite was the fried chicken- not gonna lie. The next time we're in the city, we'll visit the actual restaurant. Yum.
author: Vanessa O.

description:
Decided to order some take-out so I grabbed the BBQ pork fried rice and the fried chicken.

The chicken is fine. Good taste and texture but not too far off from the typical kind of fried chicken you'd get at a food truck. Nothing special.

The BBQ pork fried rice was disappointing. Although the rice looks really seasoned, there's very little flavor to it until you grab a piece of pork. Unfortunately, the pork I got ended up very fatty and chewy; not the tender kind of BBQ pork I'm used to.

Neither dish seemed worth the price point. The portions were fine I just didn't find the taste or texture worth it.
author: Dave K.

description:
This review is for the food - which all restaurant Yelp reviews should be about!

Everything is tasty, haven't had a bad menu selection yet. The ramen is perfect for the hangover and the ribs are to die for. You have to get the ribs. 

I've only been during lunch on weekdays so there's never been a crowd and the service is always on point. 

Will be back soon!
author: Jackie D.

description: Surrounded by lots of bars and other restaurants, this is the place for after-drink food cravings.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
The food was really good.  My friend had the Kobe beef noodles and I had the fried chicken and it was excellent. The sauce they gave with the fried chicken was next level. 

I was a pretty casual environment that felt modern but not too hipster.  For a fusion place, they had the theme just right. The service however was very slow, it took over 25 minutes for our dishes to be served, except for the fried chicken.  So that was a bit of a bummer. But overall,  i liked it and and would go back again
author: Jisan Z.

description:
I don't want to leave this review, because I want this place to remain relatively easy to get into. But it's my duty.

Holy crap, talk about fun brunch. Came STARVING with two girlfriends, and luckily the food starts coming quick :) the mimosas were flowing, friendly service, party atmosphere for a Sunday morning. The peking duck and breakfast jook stood out, shrimp fried rice and salt and pepper shrimp hit the spot, wontons and dumplings were a little underwhelming but still passable. At the end of our brunch after we paid, they didn't rush us out and were generous with the bottomless drink pours throughout brunch. And, there were a couple birthday parties going on, and they poured a sake shot for everyone in the restaurant! Very fun part of the day. 

4 stars instead of 5 because of how sugary the drinks were, and some dishes were hotter/fresher than others. But I'm now a true believer in this format of brunch, and can't wait to come back here again to nurse hangovers with greasy food and tropical morning drinks.
author: Sarah B.

description: A local favorite! Asian fusion food with a old school hip hop sound track! Korean pork tacos a must!
author: Ryanbradley N.

description: The garlic spicy noodles were AMAZING!!! We also got the short ribs and they were delicious. Next time I go to San Fran we will for sure come back!
author: Tiffany R.

description:
Yo, Asian fusion and Hip Hop. Come on.
If you love a good dining experience, get over to Chubby Noodle! They got a simple, beautiful menu that is both exciting and frustrating because you're going to want to order everything on it. The atmosphere is forsure dope. The dim lighting and the slaps got me feeling like I got a private table at the club.
Let me recommend a must have whenever you come: Korean Pork Tacos. Honestly some of the best tacos I've ever had. Yes, they beat your favorite Asian fusion food truck, they're that good.
Chubby Noodle also has a good selection of Sake, which is great to see at a hip restaurant!
author: Alex L.

description: I wanted all the noodle dishes. All. The pork fried rice was amazing perfect pork not greasy. Spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken just of the chain. The fried chicken was amazing. Sauce very garlic not over spicy.
author: Renay C.

description: Fire Isaac. The WORST customer service of all time. I will never order from Chubby Noodle again.
author: Devin H.

description:
Location: in bustling North Beach - parking will be difficult. The inside is pretty small, but still bigger than the marina location. It's LOUD. They jam out to music. 

Service: attentive and helpful servers. 

Food: 
-Garlic noodles (4/5): garlic garlic garrrrlic. I love this. I just wish they had a meat option like marina does. 
-BBQ Pork fried rice (5/5): this was absolutely delicious. not too salty, not too bland.. it was a perfect dish 
-Chubby chicken (4/5): takes way too long to come out, but still delicious. I do wish they would drain the oil off the chicken before serving, because it looked a bit gross with all the oil dripping out of it 
-Korean pork tacos (6/5): yea, that's a 6. holy s* was this amazing. this one tasted 10000% better than the one in the marina - didn't think that was even possible. Amazing tortillas and tender meat. LOVE 

great spot to come and enjoy some jams and delicious eats. uber here!
author: Shelley K.

description: Go here fairly often and the food has always been great. Jalapeño in a lot of the dishes, which my bf likes. The small menu makes decision making easier. Everything we've tried has been great.
author: S R.

description:
Good food, terrible service. Rude waitress. 
The 2 stars are for the food. We ordered pork wontons, salt and pepper shrimp and spicy garlic noodles. The spicy garlic noodles wasn't spicy but tasted good. I expected something different from the menu as they claim to serve Asian Fusion food. It was basic. I went with my friend on a Tuesday evening and were excited to try Asian fusion food. I wish the waitress allowed us some time to decide on our order. She seemed to be in a hurry. After giving us the menu card, she gave us literally a minute to place our order. We asked for some water while we explore the menu. Within a minute she came back with the water( the only good service for the evening) and asked for our order. We requested for her to give us some more time. Guess what?! She was back within a minute, again! At that point, we just asked for her recommendations. It was still okay because she might be having a bad day but this other waiter came to our table with the TRASH CAN, while my friend was still working on his plate, and asked if we were done eating. "Clearly I just wanted to get the hell out of there after that. We paid the check and left. Did not really bother to engage in any kind of conversation with anyone working there. 
Not going back there again, ever!
author: Ankita P.

description:
One word to describe this place... BRUNCH! Holy cow this place rocks. The brunch deal is phenomenal and the food and drinks are even better!!!

For $37, you get 90 minutes to drink and eat everything you want from their brunch menu. If you are going here with a few people, I highly recommend sitting at the bar! It was so fun to interact with the staff in the fun environment. BUT, if you have a larger group (4+) definitely make a reservation. This is a hot brunch spot so Saturday's and Sunday's will definitely be crowded.

For drinks, they were serving pineapple mimosas. YUM! They also have a delicious house sake :)
For food, we had just about everything on the menu. We started with the breakfast jook which was delicious but a little heavy to start the meal with! After that we had the salt and pepper shrimp, duck steamed buns, and steamed pork buns. All three were delicious... Especially the salt and pepper shrimp. After these three, we had chow mien, green beans, and shrimp wontons. Again, all three were great! So, overall, pretty much all the food is good!

We also loved the service! Everyone was super friendly and accommodating! Great work Chubby Noodle
author: Julia M.

description:
OH MAN. This place was just incredible. My girlfriends and I went to the North Beach location on a Friday about 7:30 and waited maybe 20 minutes to get a seat (perfect amount of time to grab a beer at the bar). 

The atmosphere is definitely one to consider. I personally really liked it because it had a laid back and hip vibe. Don't get me wrong, it's not a quiet place to have an intimate and romantic date. They blast hip-hop music and old school jams.

So aside from having a really cool atmosphere, the food is AWESOME. Table favorite? Definitely the chicken wings. I'm not a particular fan of chicken wings, but these somehow have a ton of flavor packed right into the breading. You could simply eat them plain and they'd be great. But the spicy sauce they serve on the side just takes them to another level. I also highly recommend the spicy garlic noodles (with a name like Chubby Noodle, you gotta get noodles right?), and the korean pork tacos (by the way, those suckers are big tacos). The tuna poke salad is pretty good, and yet of course also very expensive. The only thing I really didn't care for was the special of the day which was shrimp dumplings. It was very misleading because believe me, these were a cross between dumplings and steamed buns...just very strange and not very appetizing.

All in all I would highly highly recommend this restaurant. I can't wait to try their sister restaurant, Don Pisto's soon!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Has been going to Chubby Noodles since they were used to be at Amante. I have been to both the locations North Beach & Marina.

Ambiance:
The new place in North Beach (not new anymore) with the bamboo and wood decor is funky cool place. They blast cool hip-hop music most of the times.

Food:
Spicy Garlic Noodles with Fried Chicken (4/5): Yes Noodles topped with Fried Chicken. One of the best & most famous on the menu. You can also order fried chicken as separate entree. But i think the Fried chicken when they were at Amante was more juicier and better. 

Pork Tacos (5/5): These are the best fusion recipe they have. Flour tortillas with pork & pickled carrots & cucumbers.

Pork Ribs (4/5): Well cooked & different seasoning. I love it. But they run out of it all the time. If you want to try the ribs make sure you go early.

Fried Rice (4/5): Amazing fried rice. Rather i should say it used to be amazing. They changed the recipe few weeks back. And now it is like any other Fried Rice.

Alcohol: Good collection of Sake. Their Chubby Noodle house Sake is good.

Service (5/5): Very nice & friendly staff. Amazing People.

They have some items on the menu changing all the time. And everything i have tried till now has been good.

Overall 4/5 for food, service, ambiance, service, price.
author: Vikram S.

description:
Stumbled upon this place because yelp shows that they serve porridge. Sat down and didn't see any porridge on the menu.. Come to realize that they often change their menus so a list of ramen noodles were found, but no porridge.. at alll..... 
Decided to order the Chubby Fried Chicken and Tuna Poke during their happy hour time... Didn't see a happy hour menu, so the snacks were full priced at around ~$11-$13 per dish.. The fried chicken came out piping hot and very fresh with a type of aioli sauce.. tuna Poke had a soy sauce, scallion, sesame, ginger, marinade which you pair with a fried "asian chip". All in all, the food was okay.. the ambiance was nice, and the music was top 40s... but unless I was stuck in that area and really wanted Americanized Asian fusion dish and top 40s music, I could pass.. Maybe next time I'll try their drinks?
author: Samantha W.

description: Ate here twice in our 3 day trip to SF. The food is awesome! Drinks are cold & stiff and the music is perfect! Well worth the wait!
author: Michelle S.

description:
What a cool spot!  Sweet music bumping with fantastic food,  you can't go wrong here!   We stopped in to check this new spot and got there right before it started filling up for dinner and realized that we dropped in quite the hot spot to be!   I ordered a couple of beers of which they had a nice selection and we went right to a couple selections of noodles. Both were really great, with fresh ingredients and surprising depth in flavor.  We also went for the dumplings and found them to be very comforting as well.   

I could see this place as a local hangout,  a quick bite to eat,  or a fun date night option.   The food,  beverage,  and service don't disappoint.  Sometimes it's nice to have great food in an atmosphere that isn't quite so formal!
author: Mike M.

description: I ordered a to go from this place. It was easy to do but the food was okay...nothing special. During my brief interaction with staff when I went and picked up the food, staff seemed friendly.
author: Dani T.

description:
Oh my f***ing gawd. Haha this place is delicious!!! We frequent this joint almost on a weekly basis. The team that works here are all super friendly and embrace the neighborhood. Their tunes are on point. I don't know how they do it but every time I'm in there I'm mouthing the words to half the jams and usually dancing in my seat.

~The pork tacos are bomb!!! They have Pistos flour homemade shell that is perfectly crisp and chewy. 

~The garlic noodles are a go to simple order. A white guy pleaser (my husband)

~The lemongrass chicken vermicelli is a lady pleaser for those who wants to eat something a bit on the lighter side. Think cold noodle salad and its sooooo good. 

~The fried chicken is what they are known for and what originally got us hooked on this place when they were inside of Amante. 

~They used to have a prawn noodle dish that I was in love with but I haven't seen it resurface for a while now.

~they serve their beer in a can and thankfully they serve fort point (a local) beer. Love the Kolsch. It washes down most of the grease (tasty not nasty). 

Over all you can't go wrong eating here. Enjoy.

If you are looking to get delivery from this place use Caviar. It's reliable and gets you your grub pretty quickly and they have accurate estimates on arrival. Sign up with this link to get $10 off each of your next two orders in San Francisco.: https://bnc.lt/W9Qc/YyjfCD33Nt
author: Meg C.

description: LOVE this place for their weekend brunch and their porridge with bacon is my favorite meal here. They have great music, a bit loud - however a fun environment. The bottomless brunch is delicious and always a great time with all the ducks!! DUCKS!
author: William L.

description:
came to chubby noodle this past saturday for brunch with 5 other gf's and it was a blast. the north beach location is quite small - it was pretty packed when we all showed up at noon. 90 minute all you can eat and drink and GO! it was a lot of fun. there is basically club music playing in the background with lots of bass. brunch menu is mix-n-match 3 drinks and 15 food items, and when you sit down the waitress will put in a selection of things for you. then you just order more and more! obvi... 

food is okay for asian fusion, authenticity is out the window but creativity is high. i'd come back just for the atmosphere!
author: Christina L.

description: Came here for lunch. Had the Spicy Garlic Noodle and the Pork buns. I knew it was going to be pricey but the food was ok. The issue i had is that even though i give the waiter a 20% tip, i later check my credit card statement and the waiter gives himself more tip than i gave him...pretty shady...never going back.
author: Collin L.

description:
Top 40 music and delectable asian food? I was sold from the first 5 minutes I walked in here. This was my 3rd time at Chubby Noodle--the previous two times, I've been to the one in the Marina and both locations are awesome. They feel different too-- the Marina one is a little brighter and more bro-ey (but that's to be expected since it's the Marina). The North Beach one is a little more dimly lit with funky decor. 

This time, my friend and I split a sake, fried chicken, pork buns (on their specials list), and spicy garlic noodles. Everything was excellent, but if you need to skip something, skip the chicken-- it's a bit standard and isn't thaaaat unique in my opinion. The noodles were perfectly done and are so addicting. I forgot what I got the previous time in the Marina, but any of the noodles are bomb.com. The buns though, wowza. Those were incredible. I think I inhaled mine in about 60 seconds. The pork was super tender and came with some tangy sauce and incredible toppings that I can't remember now. 

This is a place that you can go to once a week for sure. The food is so well done, staff is amazing, and the atmosphere is awesome. Again, don't forget the top 40 music... so clutch.
author: Priya G.

description: This place is crackin'! We had reservations for 7 people on a Saturday night which I highly recommend because it gets packed very quickly. They played 90's R&B and rap music all night. So awesome. Food was good, too except for the garlic noodles. Don't order that. It was too mushy for me. I loved the pork belly tacos though!
author: Lin S.

description:
Drinks are watered down. Server accused me of pouring out my drink to take it home in my coffee cup. I would not take it home if they made me. Even after they took away my coffee cup and accused me of wanting to take it home, they came back to double check that I did not pour it in another cup and made me show him. 

Also, my family is from Hong Kong and this "dim sum" brunch is not legit. If you want real dim sum and noodles, go elsewhere. Should be marketed as a fusion restaurant rather than a noodle place. 

Not worth the money.
author: Fiona P.

description:
Love this place! I've now been to both this one and the original on Lombard street and i give this one 4 stars if I have to compare the food taste and variety to the other one. 

Overall pretty good place though. Especially if you like Asian fusion. 

Things to order:
-garlic noodles!!!! Probably shouldn't talk to anyone the rest of the night though as it's pretty pungent but sooo delicious. My favorite thing at this place
-Korean pork tacos. It comes 2 in an order for $11 so a bit expensive per taco but a good try. 
-fried chicken. Didn't think this would be that special but it sure is! So juicy inside and tastes like some herbs on top. So good and the sauce it comes with which is comparable to an aoili chipotle mayo 
-green beans. Nothing too special compared to something you can get at any other Chinese place but if you want some veggies in your meal, it's a good thing to add since it is tasty. 
-pork rib. They usually run out of this but good stuffs 

Parking at the grant location is all street and some lots but gotta watch the signs. Lots can run about $20 but I guess that's typical for SF anyway. 

Place is pretty small but we were able to get reservations same day for group of 8 at 830pm. reservation can be a hit or miss since the place is small but probably better than waiting for a longer time
author: Melissa L.

description: Delicious Asian food with lots of good, spicy options. Had the pork tacos, jalapeño noodles and fried chicken (a must try!). Service was also very fast and good. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Seema B.

description:
Overall, pretty good experience. My friends and I went for the unlimited brunch on a Sunday.

The food was pretty good. We got one of each dish and our favorites were probably the pork/duck buns. There's also free drinks (sangria/mimosa/beer), which were not bad either.

The restaurant itself was very nice, they're bumping old hiphop songs and the service was also very good.

I would come again but probably only once every so often.
author: Mark Y.

description: Great atmosphere for brunch. Some of the best Asian fusion food I've had, and my bottomless rosé glass was never empty.
author: Merilee W.

description: Delicious. Amazing service. Garlic noodles with fried chicken are a must have! Green beans and pork buns as well. Really good vibe, amazing staff, delicious food and fairly quick!
author: Alex K.

description: I am a fan of Chubby Noodle, not a raving fan...just a fan. The food is modern and fresh. We shared the garlic noodle and the duck lettuce wraps. The food was great, but my only qualm is that the prices were kind of steep for what we got. Also, I was not a fan of having to go through the kitchen to get to the bathroom. For those two reasons, I docked one star. I would recommend it to people who want some good ol' Americanized Asian food in the North Beach/ Chinatown area.
author: Kaitlyn F.

description:
This is one of my favorite brunch spots in SF! Although the bottomless mimosas / sangria + food bill isn't cheap ($37), you get a lot of bang for your buck here. My group of 7 didn't have a reservation last Saturday and the next group who DID have a reservation was coming within the hour, but instead of turning us away the wait staff let us stay until the next group arrived (it's usually 90 minutes of bottomless food and drinks) and gave us a discount.

They are super quick to refill your drinks and plates without you having to order anything in particular, so be ready to try things you might not normally eat (i.e. duck buns for me). Overall it's an awesome experience if you're ready to drink, listen to loud music, and fill up on whatever comes your way!
author: Emma B.

description:
What a great find! Cute little place. 
The servers were attentive and the food came quickly. 
The garlic noodles were wonderful with an excellent texture and a slightly spicy flavor. 
The spare ribs were tender and slightly sweet. 
The pork buns were good, but they were most underwhelming of the food we tried. 
The tacos were excellent and very filling. I would definitely recommend this place if you're looking for casual dining.
author: Deborah G.

description:
This was a great find for flavor and atmosphere. The music was amazing! I wanted to stay all night and just dance in our booth, but this place is popular and I would have felt guilty with all the people waiting outside. My friend said that the food wasn't impressionable and that you come for the ambiance, not the food, but my husband and I thought it was pretty tasty!

Garlic Noodles: Definitely garlicky. I would have preferred more kick. I added the table chili sauce to kick it up a notch.

Steamed Pork Buns: The meat was very tender and flavored well. I liked the softness of the buns in contrast to the warm, moist meat. 

Korean Pork Tacos: My favorite item of the night! The meat was delicious and it was paired well with a creamy sauce. This fatty was sad she had to share!

Garlic green beans: Off-menu item. It was deliciously garlicky and we had it made in the soy sauce instead of their usual oyster and it was still great.

Imperial Rolls: Vegetarian egg rolls that were nothing special. I didn't like the vinegary fish sauce that came on the side. Least favorite item for sure.

We also had the house sake. I am not a fan of sake so I can't give an honest opinion. However, it did mix well with the Asahi, which I quickly drowned it in! I was thankful for that :)

I wouldn't recommend to vegetarians. There aren't enough options.
author: Teresa V.

description: I had just the spicy garlic noodles and they were okay. I couldn't detect any notable spice so maybe Ill ask for them extra spicy next time. I think next time I will go with one of the other items like the taco or duck wrap because everyone says those are great.
author: Lex M.

description: This place has pretty amazing food. I've had their spicy garlic noodles which are flavorful and creep up on you with spice. I had a ramen craving and went with their ramen which was decent for a cold day. Definitely come for their noodle happy hour it allows you to try all their noodle for 6$ a plate.
author: Selina G.

description: Great atmosphere and food lived up to the hype! Will be coming back soon for the weekend brunch. The hip hop playlist definitely made the dining experience so much more enjoyable. Garlic noodles and ribs hit the spot! Great job Chubby Noodle!!! The combination of great food and music is what the City has been missing.
author: Chris S.

description: Wow.  Heard so much about this place but everyone in our party was disappointed!  Expensive and the food is not good.  The pork buns tasted off..  like they had gone bad.  The miso ramen was salty and flavorless.  The sake was harsh.
author: Chelsea D.

description: Chubby noodle's spicy garlic noodles and fried chicken are to die for. With a side of the green beans, it definitely completes the meal. I would give them a 5 but the limited food menu for the AYCE isn't as fire. Service is also pretty good and the music is most def bumpin!
author: Kristoff F.

description: Really bad service. Our server Jenna was super pissed off the entire time and barely wanted to take our order. We kept being ignored. They took our reservation for 2pm (mind you, their thing is that it's all you can eat for 1.5hrs) and they abruptly told us that there was a cut off at 3pm and it was super annoying.
author: Angela A.

description: Was told last call was 3:30 but when we went to lunch they were asking for last call at 3. We explained to them our situation but nothing was resolved
author: Louisa B.

description: Everything we ordered was delicious and the staff was helpful in helping us pick our first time visiting! The spicy garlic noodles, mmmmm yummm. The fried chicken with it, was what we thought to be a strange suggestion, was delicious! The vibes are beautiful, music is 90s rnb when we went, which just made all of it more enjoyable. Very flavorful stuff. Ohh and it's pretty affordable for what your getting.
author: Sarah H.

description: I don't know where to begin. It was flavor and food overload! So we did the all you can eat dim sum for lunch. We made reservations and I would recommend making them because it does get rather busy during the day.
author: Melissa M.

description: If you want best value for money and a boozy Sunday then go with your friends and have brunch here.  You will never forget it! The food is incredible.  Salt and pepper shrimp, green beans, ribs, wings!
author: Nathan M.

description: Fun, loud and young crowd & the food holds up to its reviews. Looks like the locals know to order takeout, though.
author: C V.

description: Honest review: garlic noodles tasted like sugar jalapeño noodles. That's the flavor, so if you're looking for garlic noodles, this is not the place for you. You'll end up leaving ripped off and disappointed. Sigh.
author: A F.

description:
If you're looking to do brunch and want something a little different this is the place! They offer a bottomless brunch with a variety of drink options (not just mimosas!) and the menu has something for everybody.

I'm dairy free/gluten free and could not have been more pleased with the way the staff helped me pick items from the menu. I was also happy to discover that many of their items are gluten free without addtional order modifications.

If you're looking for a lively brunch spot this is a great place!
author: Hayley N.

description:
Came here for dinner with a group of friends. First they blasted the music so loud that I couldn't  even start a normal conversation without literally yelling at each other. Definitely not a good place to chat with your friends.

Food is ok, pad Thai and lemongrass vermicelli are so-so, tasted just like any other places. Also ordered kimchi fried rice, tasted ok. My complaint is that the food is way overpriced-small portion and tasted just ok. The only dish that I enjoyed is the Korean pork taco.

Overall an overpriced restaurant. Would not go back.
author: Jessica L.

description: They had me at the name- then the trap and 90s hip hop music in rotation- then the food and not in that order. So happy to have stumbled upon this spot during my visit to SF. Amazing food and amazing service ! The menu is Asian fusion so you have a selection from garlic spicy noodles to tacos and even fried chicken. We had a larger party and things are meant to be shared so we were able to try a lot on the menu! Order anything and I'm sure you won't be disappointed! They didn't have a traditional saki bomber but a combo they called a happy meal  which was a 32 oz beer and shot of saki I kid you not it was the smoothest beer and saki I'd ever had! It's been real McDonald's but chubby noodles has the best happy meal on the block! Lastly you can stream their playlist on Spotify under chubbynoodlesSF which is the icing on the cake! So the moral of my review is to stay chubby ;) !
author: A P.

description: Food was decent. I didn't really understand all the hype. I am Asian, so I have pretty high standards for Asian food. Wasn't too impressed. More for the white trendy people, trying to get their fix of Asian fusion food
author: Ross S.

description:
Pretty solid. 
Service is good
Enjoyed the Garlic noodles and the pork tacos were very very good
Only thing is the music is blasted pretty loud inside
author: Jones T.

description:
Came here for the first time for brunch.  The price is $37 per person plus tax and tip for 90 minutes of unlimited Dim Sum and Drinks.

The restaurant was really festive as they were encouraging people to come dressed for Halloween in order to be eligible for a prize, and earn free shots.  Since we had a group of 10, we were able to try most of the 14 items on the menu.

Shrimp & Pork Soup - They said they would bring it, and we ask again at least one time; but, we never got to try it.

Breakfast Jook - Really good, and the best Jook I have ever had.  It comes with smoked bacon, egg, charred garlic, and scallions.

Chilled Ramen - Co-workers liked it.

Chubby Chicken Chow Mein - OK

Shrimp Fried Rice - Good.  Shrimp could have been a bit fresher.

Pork Wontons - Good.  They come served in a bowl with all the sauce at the bottom.

Shanghai Dumplings - We never saw them.

Steamed Pork Buns - These were served open style (like Peking Duck Buns).  They tasted good and were popular with our group.

Peking Duck Steam Bun - Good, but compared to the pork buns, our grouped didn't really enjoy having to construct the buns from the nice pieces of sliced duck.

Salt & Pepper Shrimp - Good; lightly breaded and deep fried.  Served with a creamy dipping sauce on the side.

Kung Pao Wings - Good; fried chicken was tender and I liked the sauce.

Orange Salad - We never saw them.

Garlic Green Beans - Good; beans were a bit firm.

Bok Choy & Mushrooms - We never saw them.

Overall, I'd give the food 3.5 stars.  In the 90 minutes given, we definitely had enough to eat.  I wish we could have tried all the dishes.

To drink, they offered:

Watermelon Mimosas - OK, but tasted really weak.

Sangria - Depending on the status of the melting ice in the pitcher, they were either good, or tasted weak.

Cans of Sapporo Bear - Not subject to being watered-down.

As they brought the bill, they provided a Cold Sake Shot Glass to everyone.  It was OK.

Overall, I'd give the drinks 2 stars.

Our group had a good time, and I would definitely like to return again.
author: Roy C.

description:
Looks like April fool's day came a day early this year.

This place is a joke that trolls on white mid-west techies with no knowledge of good Asian food.

We had been in the area for happy hour and wanted some good ramen to wash down the cold beer we indulged. We found chubby noodle, were intrigued by the four stars so walked two blocks over to indulge. Walking in, the place was packed but we grabbed one of the last two tops; in that moment, we were excited..... but those feelings quickly faded.

Our (sad) meal consisted of:

1) Started with the garlic green beans.... Which should be renamed "sodium overload green beans". Think: green beans cooked in soy sauce, with a pinch of salt and then topped with an oyster/soy sauce combo. Every bite I took I was tripling my daily sodium intake for a whopping $8.
2) MTL got the Chilled ramen noodles. By far, the worst ramen I have had in SF. Laughable, really. The meat was rough, the broth was bland (think: rain water) and it was a small bowl for $11. 
3) Spicy garlic noodles. $10. Ill preface this by saying im from the south, I douse everything I eat in siracha and I can handle my spicy. This was just a small bowl of light-garlic extra-spicy garlic noodles. Every bite taste the same, there was nothing that stuck out and it was just.... Spicy. Not good, just spicy. So much so that you couldn't even taste any garlic. 

On the way back to the car, mind you.... 3 blocks away, I threw up three times. Mostly unprocessed foods because even my stomach has standards. With Chinatown a few blocks away offering an abundance of great food at a low price point, do yourself a favor and skip this place and leave it for the white mid-west kids with no palate for good Asian food.  Even after 4 beers and a Chinese mai tai, it was still bad. 

We dropped damn near $40 after tax for a less-than-mediocre meal that didn't give me a chubby, at all. 

2 stars because our server was nice. 

Tip:
-no, just.... No.
author: Ryan L.

description: Good easy option if you are looking for some asian comfort food. Garlic noodles are simple and surprisingly good. Tacoes were tasty, but flavors didn't seem to fit my palette. Nothing wow'd nor disappointed me.
author: Christy C.

description: Awesome food san vibes. Very legit garlic noodles -- moist and soggy, not oily, and just a bit of spice.
author: C B.

description: All I can say is bomb.com. This place is the BEST!! Recommend if you are in the city with friends and want a fun party dining experience. Can't wait to go back.
author: Amanda K.

description:
To be fair almost everyone we went with (party of 10) loved this place. The wife and I were more on the meh side. Parking is basically a lost cause here unless you go to a garage and spend like $20 or so. They also blast old school hip hop which was awesomely surprising.

One thing to note first off is that this isn't a dim sum place. Some people are calling it dim sum, but it just isn't... cmon people. In reality it's an ayce Chinese buffet that serves bottomless wine, mimosa, champagne and maybe one or two traditional dim sum dishes. Don't get me wrong, the quality was still great. 

I'd recommend the jook (rice porridge), green beans and wings. Yeah I know that's a weird combo but those were my favorite things on the menu. The duck was a bit dry for me, and I'd actually prefer duck from the Chinese delis in China Town or Inner Richmond. 

The total bill ended up being about $40 per person. Not bad, but IMO a bit much for ayce Chinese food.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Brunch here is sweet as pie - a bit pricy at $40 but you get your moneys worth.

Hip-hop throwbacks, a plethora of food, and mimosas. The green beans are delicious, along with their various steamed buns. Servers are attentive to your needs.

Overall, a hip place to slug some drinks and catch a fade on a Saturday morning.
author: James K.

description:
Went there to try out this new hip-spot. I was disappointed they didn't have the coconut lemongrass noodle. However I tried the spicy garlic noodles and loved it! They also have this sparkling sake which is one of a kind. I encourage you to try it even if you don't really like wine/alcohol. It's really different and you don't wanna miss out. 

But unfortunately the other things I tried I didn't really like. The steamed pork buns, the Korean tacos and the pork ribs. Both the waiter and waitress recommended those items but they were just OK nothing too special. The pork texture-- you can tell it's good meat and cooked well, but I think the sauces didn't really complement the dishes.

One last thing-- loved the environment. Playing hip hop music really got me in the mood. It's weird hip hop music with Asian dishes... But it worked!
author: Alice K.

description:
I dont think this place is worth 4 stars for the ramen noodles. Quite disappointing for the quality. The only thing that is good in this bowl is the pouched egg! 
One star for the jose rose sangaria. 
I did not order other food. Judging from the ramen i doubt they are any good.
author: Shuang C.

description: Solid tasty dishes.  The pricing reflects that you are in SF.  The staff members are courteous and always on the move checking in with guests.  One thing they could work on is answering calls as often our calls go straight to voicemail so we can't order Togo or make reservations.
author: Emi J.

description: Went there in the Fall for a friend's bday brunch. One of the best brunches I have been to in the city. He is vegetarian so they made sure to send out special dishes just for him throughout the brunch.  Towards the end of it, Beyonce came on the speakers and before we knew it, everyone was dancing in the restaurant.  Just everyone happy and enjoying themselves.  Definitely a memorable day!
author: Laura R.

description:
My boyfriend and I rarely ever go out to the city. We really have no reason to, our lives revolve around the East Bay. His cousin works in the city and he wanted to celebrate his birthday out there, hence how we ended up at Chubby Noodle. Now, since it was a group of guys putting this shindig together, I didn't find out where we were going until the day of. That's fine, I looked it up on Yelp...I always like to know what I'm getting myself into. My boyfriend called it "Fat Noodle". He swears that he told me Chubby Noodle, but why would I be looking up Fat Noodle on Yelp by myself? Anyways, that's neither here, nor there...we figured out where we were going. 

There are two Chubby Noodle locations. I don't know my way around the city, therefore I have no idea where each district is located. But I do know where Broadway is and that is exactly where this restaurant is located. Parking is atrocious on a Saturday night. Driving up the hills is terrifying for people from suburbia. We ended up parking in a garage off of Columbus and taking a nice walk past the strip clubs. Hey, at least we were with another couple and had some thing to talk about on the drive back home. 

So to Chubby Noodle. There were only two people in our party that had ever been there before.. There was a total of 8 people with our party. It's a dark place, intimate feeling at night. It is small, so I can see why the wait can be long during peak hours. When we arrived, everyone that worked there was really friendly. The waitress came over and asked us if we had ever been, which a majority of us said no. She went over the menu, what the popular dishes were and the specials for the night. We decided that 7 of us wanted to drink, when she suggested sake. We were trying to figure out how many sake bottles and beers to get, when she suggested a big sake bottle and two big cans of beer for us to all split. When she brought the bottle, we were all kind of in disbelief. The bottle was like two large wine bottles combined. I'm not sure what we were expecting, but I can tell you that it wasn't that bottle. She poured a round for everyone, we passed them around and poured the beer into the other glasses she brought. I believe the bottle of sake was $120 and came to about $135 with the beer. Divided by 7 people, comes out to approximately $20 per person, which isn't bad. That alcohol was more than enough for all of us. If you have a large group and want to drink sake, I would suggest the big bottle and big beer cans. 

We were having a hard time deciding on what to eat because there were so many of us. I decided that we should split the table in half, two couples order what they want and the other two couples order what they wanted and then split accordingly. Our group of four ordered the fried chicken (although, they brought out two orders...we kept it because we knew we'd eat it), spicy garlic noodles, fried rice (I asked for a fried egg on the top, but it was left off) and Korean tacos. 

Fried chicken - 5/5 so good...I could have eaten a bunch of these. The dipping sauce that they include is SO good. I could eat that all day as well. 

Spicy garlic noodles - 3/5 I love noodles, but I'm not a spicy person at all. I ate it because I liked it, but it was a bit of a struggle because I'm so wimpy when it comes to spiciness. My boyfriend said he didn't like that sauce that it was made with, but I liked it. The only thing I would change is the spicy factor - because I'm a weenie. 

Fried rice - 3/5 I had read a lot about the fried rice and I was excited to try it. I just had the most amazing fried rice earlier in the week, so maybe my expectations were high. This was my least favorite dish out of the night. It wasn't terrible, but it wasn't amazing. I wonder if my mind would have been changed if the fried egg was on it. 

Korean tacos - 5/5 I read about how people really love the tacos. I now understand because these tacos are SO GOOD! I could have eaten like a dozen of these on their own. The meat inside was so flavorful, I would come back to SF just for these tacos! 

Speaking of tacos, there's a sign on the outside that says "Tacos". There is no indication of any noodles, chubby or not. We passed by this spot without even thinking that it was the actual restaurant we were looking for. I appreciated the 90's and '00's hip hop they played. Although, when it was getting close to closing time and they were trying to get people out of there, they started playing "Hello" by Adele. I know what they were doing there, get these drunk people to move along and cry about their ex's in the bar at the end of the street. I get it, when it's time to close, you want people to move along. 

Thank you Chubby Noodle, for making our rare trip to SF on a Saturday night worth it.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Unfortunately did not live up to the hype. Definitely not a place to go if you want authentic Chinese dim sum taste. Granted, I was not expecting super classic dim sum but some dishes actually came out quite bland. We went for the brunch in the morning to do the all you can eat and drink. We weren't feeling drinks (which were barely alcoholic) and the food came out super slow. They probably get you by taking a bit longer. You have 90 minutes to eat. It's better to come with about a group of 5-6,  we decided, so you can at least taste everything without feeling bad on wasting if you weren't feeling that particular dish.

We did enjoy the Salt & Pepper shrimp, the duck bao buns and the green beans. 

We did not enjoy the shrimp fried rice and chow mein...

Mind you, we came SUPER hungry and were disappointed. Plus was given a $37 + tax per person bill.
author: Ann Marie L.

description:
Yet another disappointing Asian fusion place - Asian cooking is much more than just adding daikon or ponzu to a dish, and honestly the whole aioli + avocado = fusion is a little overdone at this point. I've had better, and the prices and portion sizes here don't justify coming back again.

**Chubby fried chicken: really not sure what the angle on this dish was. The chicken was white meat but not overly dry, which was fine, and the aioli was what you would expect. The entire thing was what you'd expect, more or less. 

**Salt & pepper shrimp: decent, and I enjoyed the peppers and onion pieces that also made it into the dish. Same aioli as the fried chicken - it would've been nice to have a different combination of flavors + fried textures, but that's just me. 

**Spicy garlic noodles: this serving would be small even for a single person, let along to be shared. Noodles were overcooked and soggy, and the sauce didn't have either a spicy or a garlicky kick.
author: Kat D.

description: So I was recently told about this place from a couple of friends and seeing how north beach holds a great deal of memories for me I decided to try it out. It's on Grant street which has quite a few things to offer but this place is a jewel. I got lucky because it wasn't that crowded when I got there. I have been told that it gets quite busy here at any given time. The girl who waited on me was very nice and chill. The fried chicken is what was recommended to me from friends so that's what I went with. I know it seems weird eating chicken at a dim sum restaurant but it was great. It's really soft on the inside and just the right amount of crunch on the outside. The prices here aren't bad and I would recommend it to others.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite places in the city (and it's not just because their Spotify playlist is what throwback hip hop dreams are made of). The vibe here is just as awesome as their food. They're great for dinner, but also for their dim sum brunch. 

Items you've got to order:
Garlic Noodles
Tuna Poke
Korean Pork Tacos
Chinese Green Beans
Chinese Chicken Noodle Salad
author: Mandy A.

description:
Great spot for some casual made chic, slightly Americanized Korean / Chinese food. I wouldn't call it fusion.

The garlic noodles are good, not overpowering but also a little one note -- probably best for sharing. The yellow fin tuna yakitori is good. The bbq pork fried rice is actually pretty good and very reasonably priced. The pork tacos are okay, I didn't care for the fact that the tortillas were a bit oily/fried.

The best thing was the duck buns -- it's basically like Peking duck.

Service is fast and friendly. I'd come back.
author: Victor W.

description: I love this place! Great food, good music, nice servers. Favorite things are the ribs, garlic noodles, and ahi tuna. Solid beer list too
author: Russell W.

description: Overpriced. There's plenty of other places in the city to get better ramen or asian fusion food for a better price.
author: Kyle H.

description: My favorite spot in all of SF! The plates are best for sharing as a group. By far the best thing on the menu is the Pork Tacos. You can't come to this place and not try them. It's a popular place, but has a limited number of tables so expect to wait up to an hour if you don't come early.
author: Mark S.

description:
My wife and I were visiting from Connecticut and wandering around this neighborhood after beach blanket babylon (which was awesome). It was late (for dinner) around 1045 and we were hungry. We were in luck when we walked by the bumping music of Chubby noodle. 

Great and very quick service. A solid meal. We started with the spicy cucumbers and I got the pork Garlic Noodles and was very happy. Great texture, great flavor, perfect amount of spice. It was just a dependable and solid meal that was served hot and quickly at a reasonable price. One of the best things I had eaten during our visit to CA.
author: John L.

description:
It has become customary that when my girlfriend Alissa comes to Sf we stop here for some drinks and a very heavy snack. In her eyes, trip to the bay is not complete without fried chicken and garlic noodles and I couldn't be anymore ok about it. 

they also deliver which is great.
author: Denniz S.

description: My favorite spot in the hood. Hip Hop BBQ, fried chicken and korean pork tacos. YES PLEASE!
author: Kathleen E.

description: Came here last minute Tuesday (11/14) night after a subpar experience at another restaurant and wasn't disappointed! The area is small, but trendy! We were able to be seated right away and our waiter had some great recommendations for us. For drinks we got a Tough Titty Said the Kitty cocktail and a Villager Fort Point IPA. The drink menu was more extensive and diversified than I expected, which was great. The Tough Titty cocktail was really interesting/intriguing (in a good way) and I almost got a second. For food we got the Spicy Garlic Noodles with chicken and the Korean Pork Tacos (both recommended to us by the waiter). I love spice, but can't handle it very well so we got the jalepenos on the side of the spicy garlic noodles and I could handle it just fine. I really like the sauce that comes on the noodles and I would recommend adding the chicken for sure! The Korean Pork Tacos were also great and I loved that the cucumber on there added a little extra crunch. Overall, good service, good atmosphere, good food! I'll definitely be back.
author: Amanda F.

description: This was an unexpected highlight of my trip to San Francisco. I try to avoid the usual suspect places and while walking around Chinatown and North Beach we walked past Chubby Noodle. The club like vibe of hiphop first got my attention, but it was seeing the food on the plates of people eating by the window that drew me in.  A delicious fresh take on dim sum all you can eat brunch with all you can drink mimosas or beer. CoZy spot. The staff was very attentive. I highly recommend this spot and will be back.
author: Karen J.

description: Loved the food! And loved the atmosphere even more!! They played the best music the entire time! Defiantly a younger crowd looking to mix good food and music together.
author: Karlie J.

description:
Really, Really Good Eats!

Suggestion: try a little of everything. Decide what you love and then get seconds, and maybe thirds...

Don't be fooled by the "Tacos" sign out front. 

I HOPE they keep that sign, it makes the place that much more interesting and local. Because you either stumble into the place by accident (I've seem people come in thinking they were going to order tacos) or you are on a mission to satisfy your asian-fusion cravings.

Either way, it's a great little addition to North Beach eats.
author: Dave D.

description:
Medicorce food, overpriced, watered down drinks, rude service. $37/pp whether you eat and drink or only eat. 

We went here for brunch yesterday and it started off fun, but ended up being a negative experience. Our friends made a reservation for 6 and we squeezed into an incredibly small table. Half of our table was 6ft + and it was like we were eating on top of each other the booth was so small. 

Atmosphere - it's fun that they play music. It's just a downside that you're packed in like sardines and can't begin to get your grove on. 

Drinks - I tried their "mimosa" and "sangria" and both were awful. Super watered down and I have no idea what they use for sparkling wine but it's something I've never tried before. I asked for a glass of plain sparkling wine and they still have me a glass of ice with some sort of watered down "sparkling wine". Not a fan. The good drink was the Sapporos in a can. At least they were cold.

Food - not authentic at all, but that shouldn't be what you're expecting anyway for this sort of bottomless everything spot. The buns were good and the salt and pepper shrimp. Not impressed by the chow mein, dry chicken wings, pork dumplings (very dry and tasted like cheap pork), or ramen (not at all ramen FYI). The jook was good, but they don't bring you a spoon or anything to eat it with. My friend asked for a spoon and it never came after asking twice. I finally gave up waiting and ate some of it with chopsticks and it did taste good.

Service - what really ruined our experience. Our server Sean blew it for no reason. He was really nice throughout our brunch and apologized several times for being a bit behind because it was so busy. We said we totally understood and no problem. We were getting along fine, until the end. He brought us our check and we all put our cards in and he took it away to run our cards. In that time another (7th) friend joined us who we were meeting up with and sat down at a random chair nearby to wait while we settled the bill. We offered him some of the chicken wings on our table half jokingly because we though they were so awful and now cold. Apparently he was hungry enough and ate 2 of them. Then the server Sean comes out of no where and says he fixed the bill, and added our 7th friend because he has to charge for everyone who's at the table within 90 minutes because it gets so crazy and they can't tell sometimes how many people are at each table and who's eating or not eating. Do you not like tips or something? WTF. You literally waited on a table of 6 people (really only built for 6 children) for 90 minutes and you think we were hiding a 7th body somewhere? He said we could talk to the manager if we wanted to dispute it and we said YES. We said we refuse to pay $37 for 2 awful chicken wings and we were shocked we were provided such bad service and he was very nice and gave us the 7th meal on the house. Thanks. We were having a great time and it was ruined by poor, narrow minded customer service. Sean should have gone to his manager and not involved us and said I'm charging that table for 6 because their friend just showed up as they are leaving. We left feeling like chicken wing thieves, when in reality we just spent a ton of money on food and drinks that costs them nothing to make. 

Not a fan of any aspect of this place. The best part was the cute mini rubber duckies they put in your drinks. I took a ducky and I'll be popping it my real sparkling wine at a much better brunch somewhere in the future.
author: Juliet S.

description:
They've done it again.  Welcome addition to the hood.  If you want to listen to some good 90s hip hop (and with some michael jackson and early 2000's stuff thrown in), and down a good beer or some sake (or wine), and some eats - this is your place.  

You probably already know their recipe for success, but it's got a "more asian" flair - meaning a small variety of skewers and some "asian" flavors.  

The mustard chicken wings were on point.  Fried, but not deep fried (ie not battered), and had a great mustard flavor.  The Meatball skewers were nice and juicy.  The chicken and avocado skewers were also juicy, with the addition of the avocado sauce.  Could have had a bit more kick for my tastes.  The swordfish skewers also well prepared - not dry in the slightest with a great flavor.  

While that apparently was not enough for my solo self - the duck buns were a last minute addition (I think they're already on the regular chubby menu), and they also did not disappoint.

I accompanied this all with a Headlands Brewery Groupe G Belgian RyePA - once again glad to support local.  They threw in a glass of sake of which they said "this is called 'a good day'" - hey, I can't complain.

Overall, a great addition - look forward to spending a lot more evenings here.
author: Jason J.

description: Food is delicious! Unfortunately our wait staff was unpleasant and stingy.. for a buffet! 7/10. Do better!
author: Ryan B.

description:
Food 3/5. Ambience 4/5. Photo opportunity 5/5. 
We went in on a Sunday lunch time and only had another table occupied. With that said, the music was nice and we ordered food from the specials. 

The food was as good as most 'Asian fusion' restaurant but definitely wasn't the best I've tried. 
We ordered the Chicken Chow Mien and Lemongrass coconut broth noodle with chicken. Both were honestly okay in flavor but wasn't exceptional either. I think it lacked salt. 

The other thing I ordered was the alcoholic beverage from the brunch menu. Looked good but taste alright. 
Overall, it's a nice location if you are looking for average food.
author: WQ C.

description: Food was great. Service was equally good. Being so close to Chinatown, it wasn't the best value for the type of food, but its a totally different atmosphere they're presenting. Definitely worth a try.
author: Art C.

description:
The music and dim sum drew us in! 
From out of town and Enrique took great care of us. 
The salt and pepper shrimp was amazing. And the green beans were exceptional. We weren't a fan of the pork tacos, so Enrique hooked us up with a shot of sake and took the tacos off the bill. 
Amazing service. 
Great food.
Thanks again, Enrique!
author: Eeda G.

description: not sure how all the items are for the fusion brick and mortar joint with loud music, but the fried chicken pieces were executed well and same for the pork ribs, nice sweet soy jalapeño onion, but the prices are bit too high for what you get.
author: Rob C.

description:
I'd give five stars if I were only reviewing the excellent food and service. The ramen, the green beans, and the hand rolls were superb. Delicious sake and our server was attentive and kind.

One star because the music is misogynist and offensive. As four women dining together, we heard the words "b*tch," "p*ssy," and "ho*s" too many times to feel comfortable.

I understand that you are catering to a certain demographic, but why? The neighborhood is hurting for delicious, authentic food like yours. Make it welcoming for all of us. We'll go back if you do away with the demeaning music at an unnecessarily high volume.

But once again, food was excellent! Kudos to the kitchen staff.
author: Shayne W.
